title: 47 Lessons
description: Things I've learned.
fullText:
Every year, for my birthday, I collect my thoughts. This year I want to share some things I‚Äôve learned: one lesson for each year I've been around. You might agree or disagree with them; maybe a bit of both. But they‚Äôre ideas I‚Äôve picked up that, at the very least, are insights into how I think. Maybe they‚Äôll be useful to you, too.

Previous birthday posts: 46 books, 45 wishes, 44 thoughts about the future, 43 things, 42 / 42 admissions, 41 things.

Every project, every major task, is worth taking your time over, both to plan and to do.

Most food cooks better if you do it with care, treating the ingredients, your tools, and the people who will eat what you‚Äôre making with respect. Most projects come together better that way too.

When I‚Äôve rushed something together, I‚Äôve almost always come to regret it.

Aiming for perfection is a trap.

Even if you take things slowly, you‚Äôll get stuff wrong. It‚Äôs part of doing anything meaningful. So rather than planning your project within an inch of its life, the best thing to do is start small, build in tests so you can figure out if you‚Äôre on the right track, learn from them, build incrementally, and keep going. The earlier you can get outside feedback, or some kind of signal from the outside world about whether you‚Äôre doing the right thing, the better.

I have this slightly reductive metaphor I use for both writing code and English, and I think it probably works for any project of substance:

Think of your project as a corridor. You have a bouncy ball and you need to get it to the end.

You could spend a long time trying to get a steady shot that hits the wall at the end of the corridor dead on. But you could also bounce the ball off the walls all the way down. It‚Äôs maybe less elegant, it‚Äôs maybe messier, but you still hit the wall at the end. And you probably get there a lot faster, with a lot less stress.

Another way to put it is this: if you accept that you‚Äôll be wrong, you‚Äôll approach your problem differently to how you would if you assumed you were right. You‚Äôll talk to people earlier, you‚Äôll get outside feedback, you‚Äôll run tests. Even if you were right, those aren‚Äôt bad things to do. Conversely, if you assume you‚Äôre right, you probably won‚Äôt do anything to de-risk your idea, and you could still be wrong. And then you‚Äôll have burned a bunch of time on something that doesn‚Äôt hit the mark, which might not have happened if you‚Äôd approached it with humility instead of hubris.

Life is a project. You can assume you‚Äôll do everything right or that you‚Äôre really smart, but that probably won‚Äôt get you very far. We all need feedback. We all need to learn and then course correct and then do it all over again. All we can do is iterate on ourselves.

It‚Äôs weird to me how many people don‚Äôt: they‚Äôll try and give you directions even if they don‚Äôt know the way to a place, or they‚Äôll spin their wheels forever instead of suffering the indignity of going out and asking someone.

The cool thing about admitting you don‚Äôt know, and just asking someone if you need to find something out, is that it leads to a different kind of conversation. If someone asks me something and I don‚Äôt know the answer, particularly if there‚Äôs a vulnerability to not having that particular piece of knowledge, telling them lets them know that I‚Äôll be real with them. But more than that, it just gets me to where I need to be faster. I‚Äôm not wasting time on face-saving bullshit. And there‚Äôs precious little time to waste.

You are what you tolerate. But you are also what you notice, what you spend time with, and what you choose to dismiss.

If you allow your attention to be shaped and manipulated by someone else, you are what they are trying to make you to be.

Pay attention to your attention.

I originally thought this famous advice was maybe unfair: didn‚Äôt it prioritize knee-jerk assessments? But it‚Äôs not about snap judgments; it‚Äôs not your first reaction to someone. It's about paying attention when someone actively reveals their values to you. If someone shows you who they are, believe them the first time. And I‚Äôve come to understand that Maya Angelou is right.

Even the smallest red flags matter. The person who tells you the world would be better if men and women played to their gender‚Äôs strengths. The person who, on being inconvenienced by local rail drivers striking for better pay, exclaims that they can‚Äôt wait until they‚Äôre all replaced by robots. The person who is needlessly rude to a waiter or the person behind the desk at a coat check. These are the kinds of small exchanges that are indicators of a mindset that dictates how they show up in the world. It might seem kind to overlook them, but it‚Äôs wiser not to. There‚Äôs always something more.

What I mean by this is: if you allow something to continue, you help normalize it.

People often say this about management: if you tolerate mediocre work, your team becomes mediocre. And, sure, that‚Äôs important in a work environment.

But it‚Äôs also true in life. If you allow someone to regularly belittle you, you become belittled. If you allow someone to cause harm, you cause harm.

When my son was a baby, I quickly learned that while babies can‚Äôt talk through words, they have a full spectrum of communication that, generally speaking, gets their point across. I‚Äôd assumed that babies were a little bit like that old app Yo, where the only notification you could send or receive was a one-note ‚Äúyo‚Äù. That was so far from being true.

There‚Äôs no such thing as a cry that doesn‚Äôt have an underlying meaning, from the practical ‚Äî I‚Äôm hungry, I‚Äôm uncomfortable ‚Äî to the existential ‚Äî I‚Äôm lonely, I need a hug.

We learn words, we pick up the cultural dressing of the society around us, but we don‚Äôt stop crying. Those underlying signals perhaps become more complicated as we age, but they‚Äôre still there, all around us as subtext behind what everyone says and does. There are the words, and there‚Äôs the message behind the words.

There‚Äôs a thing I learned from Corey Ford, which I think may have been inspired by some of the work Carole Robin did on interpersonal relationships at Stanford‚Äôs Graduate School of Business.

Open, 360-degree feedback is vital on any high-performing team (or functional community). If you let friction between people linger, it tends to grow, and can sink the culture of a team; it‚Äôs the kind of thing that kills startups and leads to people leaving companies. You need to be able to bring things up and talk about it in a non-accusatory way.

That doesn‚Äôt come naturally. So you have to practice.

He‚Äôs got a great process that I‚Äôve used for over a decade called the one-on-one gift exchange. The details of it aren‚Äôt important here, although it‚Äôs worth checking out. He advises that you do it on a regular schedule, whether you have something specific to bring up or not. In doing so, you make giving and receiving feedback just a thing that you do regularly, and it makes it easier to give the hard feedback when it inevitably comes up.

All communication is like this. You‚Äôve got to practice. And you‚Äôve got to keep practicing, otherwise your communication skills atrophy. And it turns out that open, honest, bidirectional communication is essential to every kind of relationship, from business to families to romantic to friendships. Otherwise things build up and build up, and, if you leave them unaddressed, they snap.

I came from a context that didn‚Äôt matter: some guy writing code in Edinburgh, way outside of the centers of tech or media power. I got used to being critical about products and teams. Some of those criticisms were meaningful; some were not.

The first time this bit me was when I worked at Medium. At some company happy hour (there were a lot of those during the era I was there), I talked about how silly a very famous product design was. ‚ÄúI built that,‚Äù someone said. Over time, my voice became more influential, as I took bigger roles. Despite this increased attention, I sometimes continued to run my mouth over stuff that didn‚Äôt matter, offending people for no reason.

Some things do matter. If you‚Äôre colluding with fascists, destroying the environment, or causing active, obvious harm, you deserve to be called out. On the other hand, a design decision or a voice that you don‚Äôt quite agree with deserves a little more care. Every single thing is made by real people with real lives and complicated contexts. There‚Äôs a difference between speaking truth to power and dunking on someone‚Äôs work. Choose your targets carefully.

If you‚Äôre not familiar with it, Plato‚Äôs allegory of the cave goes something like this:

Imagine prisoners who have spent their entire lives chained inside a cave facing a wall. Behind them is a fire; their captors cast shadows from various objects and puppets. Because those shadows are the only things they‚Äôve ever known, they‚Äôre reality for the prisoners.

Imagine, then, that a prisoner is freed and compelled to leave. They see the fire; because they‚Äôve never seen light so bright before, they‚Äôre temporarily blinded. Then they‚Äôre dragged outside and the sun is brighter still. Eventually, as their eyes adjust, the world outside is clearer and more detailed than the shadows ever were.

So the prisoner goes back into the cave to free the others. It‚Äôs dark in there, so they‚Äôre blinded again. The prisoners infer that whatever‚Äôs outside must have hurt the freed prisoner. So the freed prisoner must have been corrupted and whatever‚Äôs outside must be dangerous. They‚Äôll defend themselves from being freed and dragged outside themselves, potentially to the death.

Here‚Äôs where I‚Äôve come to differ with the common understanding of the parable:

Each of us is in our own cave. We don‚Äôt have a shared reality; we all get our own shadows.

The dangerous bit of the story isn‚Äôt being in the cave or being freed. It‚Äôs going back, or never having been a part of that particular cave to begin with and wandering in to provide perspective. There are so many people who believe their context is the right one, that the shadows they‚Äôre seeing aren‚Äôt just reality, but comfortable and right.

Take it from a Third Culture Kid who‚Äôs moved around a bit.

The more caves you‚Äôve seen and the more times you‚Äôve been forced into the light by the gift ‚Äî or shock ‚Äî of another perspective, the clearer you can see the limits of any one view of the world. But that's scary as hell for the people who won't adjust themselves to the light, who want their version of the cave to be everybody's.

If you've only ever lived in one town, one state, or one country, you're seeing narrow shadows of how the world works. We all know the people in the cozy town who see the arrival of outsiders as a threat to their ‚Äúway of life‚Äù. Geography, culture, and the assumptions of the people we connect with shape what seems natural, what seems possible, what seems inevitable, and it can make a new perspective ‚Äî which, too often, is a new person ‚Äî feel like a threat.

One of my favorite things is psychogeography: a way to explore built environments by taking arbitrary routes or following interpersonal, human-driven connections to places rather than taking a direct, logical route.

If you explore Venice, you‚Äôll probably find the same tourist destinations as everybody else. That‚Äôs not nothing: they‚Äôre beautiful. But if you go and find, for example, the narrowest alleyway in Venice, you‚Äôll leave the crowds, walk through neighborhoods where people actually live, and see more about the culture and nature of the city than if you‚Äôd stuck to the tour.

I would have earned a lot more money if I‚Äôd dedicated myself to engineering and just focused on software and product inside the tech industry. But it would have been a hell of a lot less interesting, and a hell of a lot less fulfilling. Meandering means going somewhere new.

I‚Äôve found that the more someone adheres to a template for living, the more affronted they are by people who don‚Äôt adhere to one.

There‚Äôs a kind of xenophobia that‚Äôs at the root of conservatism. If you feel like being ‚Äúnormal‚Äù is a moral good, then it follows that someone who isn‚Äôt normal is immoral. They‚Äôre to be feared ‚Äî and, potentially, converted.

Most overtly, we see that in peoples‚Äô reactions to trans people, to marriage equality, or to immigrants coming from other cultures or with minority skin colors. But it also manifests in smaller intolerances: the microaggressions that many people have to deal with every day. It‚Äôs not just MAGA; it‚Äôs the libertarian, predominantly male norms of the software industry, or New York City‚Äôs implicit dress codes.

I‚Äôve sometimes wondered if these templates provide some stability for people who struggle with empathy, who find it difficult to imagine another human being‚Äôs interior life. If you don‚Äôt know how other people work, established patterns can be reassuring. Conversely, people who don‚Äôt fit into them are unsettling.

For some reason, I give off a kind of conventional vibe, which means people feel safe sharing these fears with me. The British accent, ‚Äúsafe‚Äù haircut, and slightly self-deprecating demeanor don‚Äôt scream ‚Äúpart-Indonesian multinational third culture kid who cares about undermining centralized systems of power‚Äù. But that‚Äôs what I am.

So I‚Äôve had those encounters. The guy who, over a drip coffee in San Mateo, told me that the problem with the world is that women don‚Äôt know their place anymore. The one who, at a pub in North Oxford, said that, you know, he doesn‚Äôt know what‚Äôs wrong with Europeans. The manager with the pristine haircut who complained that people who want inclusion ‚Äúwant so many other things‚Äù. And why doesn‚Äôt everyone speak English?

Spoiler alert: I am not a safe person to have those conversations with.

I tend to feel sorry for people who feel like they have to abide by a template, but that ebbs away as soon as they advocate for someone else‚Äôs subjugation. The templates defend themselves. But everyone deserves to live on their own terms.

It‚Äôs really easy to say things like, ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt do heights‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm a bad public speaker‚Äù in the same register as ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt reach high shelves‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôm allergic to peanuts‚Äù. But they‚Äôre different kinds of things.

The first are surmountable. You might not be a good public speaker now, but most great public speakers had practice. The question isn‚Äôt, ‚Äúcan you be a good public speaker‚Äù, but ‚Äúdo you want to be?‚Äù Because if you do, and you put your mind to it, you probably can.

I started out by wanting to write for a career. I‚Äôve been a software engineer. I‚Äôve founded two startups. I was a venture capitalist, somehow. I was also a film reviewer and a barista. I‚Äôve sworn blind that I couldn‚Äôt draw and have also drawn well. Everyone changes. We‚Äôre all in flux. We can all grow.

That‚Äôs true for industries and countries. We can wax nostalgic all we want about how it used to be, but (1) it probably never actually was exactly as we remember, (2) we can never go back there. Time doesn‚Äôt work that way. Even if we had a fully-kitted-out Delorean with a functional flux capacitor, our presence would change that reality. It cannot exist.

I sometimes find myself nurturing a kind of homesickness for different eras of my life. Some of them make me so sad that my chest aches. I miss people, I miss places, I miss the rhythms and values of my life back then. But I can‚Äôt go back. There‚Äôs no email I can send, no journey I can take, that will return me there. It‚Äôs more important to figure out what was so special about them, understand how important those values are to me, and make decisions about my future with them in mind.

And so much else. Rather than worrying about how the news industry used to be, we need to invent how it will be in the future. Instead of yearning for the glory days of the open web, we need to build something new. Instead of wistfully dreaming about a time before Donald Trump, we must prepare for the time after him. We all have to move forwards.

Of course, then you‚Äôve got another problem.

Most of the time, our work is in the hands of the right people. We make good decisions hiring, we bring new people we trust into our communities, and everything works well.

But sometimes that doesn‚Äôt happen. Maybe someone‚Äôs had a bad day, or they‚Äôre sick, or someone who doesn‚Äôt understand the context has to fill in for some other reason. Suddenly it becomes apparent that we don‚Äôt have systems of control: the most sensitive tasks don‚Äôt have safeguards that ensure the right thing happens. Our process has been based on norms and traditions rather than enforced checks.

These days, modern code is written using the Pull Request, a feature that was streamlined and therefore popularized by GitHub. Instead of an engineer just writing software into the codebase, they submit it as a change; another engineer checks it over and either requests changes or gives it the okay. Usually, an automated system also runs tests against it to make sure the code fits into the standards and guidelines of the codebase. The result is a system of control that has at least two levels of check: the human reviewer and the automated tests. Damaging mistakes can still happen, but far fewer than if you were writing code without oversight and uploading it directly to a production server.

Writing a rule, law, or process to contain a system of control isn‚Äôt a vote against the trustworthiness of whoever is responsible when it‚Äôs written. It‚Äôs a way of ensuring that whoever the next person is can‚Äôt abuse it.

There‚Äôs a lot that I could say about the second Trump administration. One way of looking at it is as a penetration test for American democracy: finding the parts of the American system of government that were held together with norms and traditions instead of well-defined systems of control.

That‚Äôs been the worst-case scenario. But the effect of every bad manager, every disgruntled employee, and every bad actor, big and small, can be mitigated by the same principle.

It stands to reason. A brand is a business entity‚Äôs marketing identity, which inherently is designed to manipulate you into having a reaction to it. Why would you trust that?

One of the remarkable things I‚Äôve observed in journalism is that a lot of people in the industry assume that the general public should love them. Journalism provides a lot of societal value, so the fact that trust in it is at an all-time low means the public needs to be educated about it. The reason they don‚Äôt trust it is they don‚Äôt know enough about it!

I want to play the Family Feud buzzer sound here. Ehhh ehhh. The reason people don‚Äôt trust journalism is that it‚Äôs talking past them, not to them, and it‚Äôs certainly not listening to them. They see the logos and the wordmarks, rather than a real human being taking the time to be real with them. The lesson of young people turning to YouTube and TikTok is not that young people love vertical streaming video, it‚Äôs that they‚Äôre tired of corporate bullshit and want to see a real human face meeting them where they‚Äôre at.

It‚Äôs a scary prospect for a newsroom, or for any organization. A brand is an identity for the full collection of people. In contrast, a real human face is someone who might not always be employed at that company. If a community has built up a relationship with a person, they may leave when the person finds a new job. The brand owners want to invest in relationships they can keep for themselves.

But the public doesn‚Äôt care about that. They just want to have an actual conversation with a person. They‚Äôre looking for human authenticity and a personality that doesn‚Äôt try to authoritatively dictate the truth to them.

We all just want to connect with people, not be marketed at. It‚Äôs about relationships and humanity. Community doesn‚Äôt care about your ligatures. It wants to be seen.

If only managers receive public gratitude from leadership for a team‚Äôs accomplishments, then the culture prioritizes hierarchy and devalues the contributions of the individual contributors who actually do the work.

If only certain roles receive gratitude from leadership, then the culture only really values those roles, and sees other positions as subordinate.

Over time, if people are doing hard but thankless work, they‚Äôre unlikely to stick around, and the work will suffer.

Everyone who shows up to work is making a contribution. What you‚Äôre doing couldn‚Äôt happen without them. They‚Äôre three-dimensional people who care about their place in the community and want to be respected. So treat them like they are ‚Äî and thank them.

If you‚Äôre on a team that writes code, every codebase you write from scratch is something new that you have to maintain. Write enough of those without increasing the size of the team and you‚Äôll find that everybody is in maintenance mode all of the time. (Self-hosting someone else‚Äôs code has a similar maintenance overhead.)

If you‚Äôre in a company that buys services, every new service you buy is something new that you have to pay for. 

If you add complications to your life, the emotional and administrative overhead adds up in similar ways. You might think you can take it on, and you probably can, but as the complications and responsibilities grow, so does the overhead of living. And suddenly you might find that you‚Äôre tired and stressed all the time. The trick is, it sometimes happens without you really meaning it to. Life accumulates.

The trick is knowing which kinds of overheads you can manage, and when.

I‚Äôve written a lot over the years about how if you‚Äôre making a product, you need to know who it‚Äôs for, and make sure it actually solves someone‚Äôs problem. ‚ÄúScratching your own itch‚Äù is something that open source developers in particular do a lot of, but if you do that, you may spend a long time, and potentially a lot of money, working on something and find out at the end that it doesn‚Äôt quite solve a problem for anyone but you.

But that doesn‚Äôt mean that there‚Äôs anything wrong with scratching your own itch.

I think it‚Äôs the wrong way to go about starting a business (be it a startup, small business, or non-profit). In those situations, you need to know who your customers are, you do need to understand if what you‚Äôre making is useful, and you do need to understand if anyone will buy or support what you‚Äôre building in the context of the model you‚Äôve created for it.

But not everything has to be a business. Not everything has to be sustainable.

There‚Äôs a word for a creative act that is self-led in this way, regardless of whether the medium is code or words or paint or anything else: art. It‚Äôs always okay to make art. We need more art, all the time. Art is one of the core things that makes us human; it‚Äôs one of the core substrates that holds society together.

But you‚Äôve got to know whether you‚Äôre making art or building a business: whether your center of gravity, your great adjudicator, is your customers or your heart. By understanding this, you‚Äôve set up your own expectations, and you know which tools to deploy. With art, you can follow your heart more ambitiously. With customers, you can obsessively serve them. In both cases, you can cut the ambiguity.

It‚Äôs not that one is more valuable than the other. They‚Äôre just different things.

Back when I worked for Matter Ventures, we would have intense recruitment periods for our accelerator. For a few weeks, I‚Äôd work twelve hour days, sitting on a hard wooden stool at a homemade wooden table made out of a door, and listen to pitches from early-stage startups that hoped to obtain our funding. It ran the gamut from incredibly smart applications that I‚Äôd never seen before, through barely-there ventures fueled by magical thinking, to outright grifts.

A lot of first-time entrepreneurs were adamant that we should fund them because of their values. They were good people doing something ideologically wonderful in the world. They saw our investment like a magical grant.

But it wasn‚Äôt a grant. We were a mission-driven accelerator, investing in ventures with the potential to help create a more informed, empathetic, and inclusive society. But we were still a for-profit venture firm. We needed to invest in startups that had the potential to provide an exponential financial return. There were plenty of lovely people whose projects had lots of value ‚Äî but we couldn‚Äôt fund them using our model.

When I was building Known, we couldn‚Äôt get investors to the point where they had conviction we would give them that return. They were very nice to us, and we had some good coffee conversations - but that‚Äôs where it ended. We couldn‚Äôt tell that story. The best founders pivot their startups until they‚Äôve caught onto something that looks like it will grow quickly. That requires killing your darlings, as writers call it; letting go of the things you love that just aren‚Äôt working. That‚Äôs not what we chose to do.

Every venture fund is working for their limited partners (the people who put money into them). That‚Äôs most likely to be a financial return ‚Äî ideally a startup will return a substantial multiple of the money that was invested into it ‚Äî but it might also be a strategic return. (Consider why NVIDIA might invest in AI startups, or why the CIA might invest in social media - which, by the way, is a thing they do.) Every limited partner has a different agenda; every venture firm has its own investment hypothesis.

The same is true of non-profit grants, as it happens: donors put money into them, too, and they also have their own agendas.

If you‚Äôre not raising money with the needs of the venture partners / non-profit funders and the agendas of the limited partners or donors in mind, you‚Äôre not taking it seriously. It‚Äôs not magic. It‚Äôs a financial transaction. You don‚Äôt get it because you deserve it; you get it because the funder thinks you‚Äôll give them the return they need.

And of course, this is how power centralizes.

Nine times out of ten, it‚Äôll fix your computer problem. Really. Try it before you ask someone else. I‚Äôm begging you.

You need sleep. You really do. You only think you don‚Äôt because you don‚Äôt physically drop dead or stop talking when you‚Äôre underslept. But you‚Äôre basically another person. Go to bed.

I‚Äôm not sure where it came from, but over time I developed a kind of shame just for being me: an underlying sense that there was something fundamentally wrong with me, but nobody would tell me what it was. It arrived one day when I was a teenager and never left. I imagined that there was a magic incantation that I didn‚Äôt know, but I could never be good enough. I‚Äôd never be worthy of the adulation I placed in other people; if I wanted to be liked, I needed to mask to be more like them. I desperately wanted someone to really see me and ‚Äî despite that ‚Äî know that I was okay.

The thing about feeling like you just need an ally, or someone who will tell you at last that you‚Äôre okay, is that it puts you in an incredibly vulnerable position. You don‚Äôt need someone who will tell you you‚Äôre okay; you don‚Äôt need a superficial ally. You need people who you can be in community with, who you can build relationships with over your life.

It creates vulnerability in another way, too. If you don‚Äôt like yourself, if you feel like you don‚Äôt matter, you can trick yourself into thinking that nothing you do matters, either. And there probably are people who care a great deal about you; consequently, what you do does matter. So you can make decisions that inadvertently hurt people you care about a great deal. You can fail to fight for relationships that have the potential to transform the entire fabric of your life. You can be passive about the stuff that really matters in life. You can find yourself in a place where you ignore your goals, values, and ideals.

So I‚Äôve learned that you need to find ways to feel good about yourself; to respect yourself; to care for yourself. It‚Äôs not a selfish act. It allows you to show up in the way the people you care about need you to, which in turn allows you to build better relationships, better community with them. It allows you to take bets on yourself and build the life you really want to live. It allows you to be you, on a really fundamental level.

But if you don‚Äôt do that? The spiral is hard to escape from. The people you care about will tire of your disrespect. And those relationships may take years to repair.

Yes, my metabolism is slower than it ever used to be. I‚Äôm definitely more tired. My back is a little more tense. I find it harder to shift into a creative mode.

But let‚Äôs look at how my life has changed. I have a much more demanding job and my time is less my own.

In my twenties I was the founder of a bootstrapped startup and could set my own parameters, including when I worked and when I didn‚Äôt. Nobody was checking my work except our customers: I had remarkable creative freedom. I didn‚Äôt have a kid, so I could walk seven or eight miles a day (and did). I hung out with friends more often, saw live music more often, went to the movies, and spent more of my life being active and having fun as a percentage.

I‚Äôm pretty sure that if I returned to that level of activity, my metabolism would increase. If I made more of a commitment to fun and had fewer parameters in my work, I would find it easier to shift into a creative flow state. If I was less stressed about money, I would sleep better at night. In fact, before my mother died, I was running 5K every day, and my body, my mind, and my soul, frankly, were all improving.

Let‚Äôs be clear: every body is different. Biology is real. But not every mid-life physical decline is inevitable. It‚Äôs that the demands on your time, your energy, your brain increase. There‚Äôs more overhead. And it takes a toll.

For a long time after she died, I could hear the gentle click of my mother breathing through her cannulas. It followed me home to her house in Santa Rosa, and across coasts to my new home in Elkins Park. Sometimes I could hear the wheels of her feeding tube stand rolling across the floor.

These sounds lived in me. I couldn‚Äôt let them go. Not with all they represented.

We washed her, my sister and I, right at the end. A final act of care. But not one of goodbye.

My cousin warned me that the grief could sneak up and grab you, unsuspecting, and it did: I found that I had to pull off the road or hide myself in a public bathroom and let it out. I don‚Äôt know what other people made of the sound of my sobbing, if they heard it. It didn‚Äôt matter.

It had been a long journey. I‚Äôve written about it from time to time, partially to explain myself, and partially to exorcise it. It doesn‚Äôt represent my mother, and shouldn‚Äôt, except in that she fought with so much life-force, and maintained so much good humor and kindness until the very end. I want to remember her smiling at a joke or angry about the world, not her prone fragility in a hospital bed.

Grief is just this: the loss of her, the loss of the family with her in it, the loss of her life and our lives and how everything was before we knew she was going to die. Some days, moving forwards is easy. Some days, the sadness ambushes you, and it‚Äôs all you can do to keep breathing. Every day, I feel it in my limbs, in a new heaviness to every day. If you cut me open like a tree I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll see it in my rings.

Grief is not the same thing as trauma.

The trauma is of seeing my mother in that bed, knowing she didn‚Äôt want to die in a hospital after that decade-long struggle, and not being able to do anything about it because the doctors she needed 20 liters of oxygen and she would have suffocated if we‚Äôd moved her.

It‚Äôs of learning what palliative care means, first-hand, and understanding that they would pump her with drugs and starve her until the end came.

It‚Äôs of seeing her at the bottom of the stairs and staying with her until the ambulance came.

It‚Äôs of yelling at her to wake up after the surgeon scraped off the crust around her lungs, her lips blue, her breathing shallow, and thinking this was really the end this time.

It‚Äôs of moving thousands of miles to be with her, sure she was about to die, sure that I would get the same sickness, and losing the person I thought I would spend my life with, not knowing if I had time left.

It‚Äôs of my cousins, and my aunt, and my Grandma. Everyone we have lost to this horrible disease.

It‚Äôs of, even now, not being able to dream about my mother, not hearing her voice except for the videos I took of her, except for that one time I heard her say, ‚Äúoh my God, you guys,‚Äù clear as day in the dead of night.

It‚Äôs layered like rock, a thick crust of fight or flight burying layers of sadness and images that make me sit upright with my heart pounding.

I‚Äôve only recently made peace with disrupting those layers and mining to its core. Losing the trauma is not the same thing as losing her. It‚Äôs not saying that she doesn‚Äôt matter; it‚Äôs not saying that any of the people we‚Äôve lost don‚Äôt matter. Quite the opposite. It just says, it‚Äôs time to keep living. For them and for me.

Oversharing is real. Sometimes it can be too much. If you‚Äôve found you‚Äôve done that, you might need to retreat for a moment or two; reassure the person you‚Äôre talking to that everything is okay. That you‚Äôre normal, you know? You can follow the template too. You‚Äôre safe.

Not forever. Just for a beat. Masking is overhead, after all.

You know those little white cups from In-N-Out? You pull on their edges and they unfold and unfold. They‚Äôre surprisingly large! So much room for ketchup! Do you need that much ketchup? Maybe!

(You know about the secret menu, right?)

I stood in Doctors, a real ale pub in Edinburgh that was never my favorite but was a short walk from the university buildings. I‚Äôd just presented at a tech meetup at the Appleton Tower, explaining to folks what Known did and why I thought the indieweb was important. I‚Äôd been back for a few days; I just planned to be in Edinburgh for a week.

Someone who I‚Äôd known for years ‚Äî not well, just an acquaintance, but someone who I thought was generally smart and knew what they were talking about, more or less ‚Äî was saying that she didn‚Äôt know why I‚Äôd left. ‚ÄúWhen they moved to California, they left you,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI would have said, ‚Äòsorry, Mum, it‚Äôs your own fault.‚Äô‚Äù

I‚Äôve played that conversation back in my head for years. At the time, I was so stunned that I didn‚Äôt have a real response. It was so far outside of my spectrum of values that I didn‚Äôt see it coming. Why would you say that to someone who had ripped their whole life up to be closer to their terminally ill mother? Why would you even think it?

I did do those things. When I was thirty-two years old, I moved to California for what I thought was a temporary visit. I ripped my life apart in the process.

When I was twenty-three years old, nine years earlier, my parents moved to California to be closer to my Oma. It seemed like a no-brainer. Of course you‚Äôll be there for your family. We‚Äôre close. We love each other. We‚Äôll support each other.

My move was a decision point: I didn‚Äôt know, exactly, where my life in Edinburgh was going. It could have gone to amazing places ‚Äî and it also might not have. I knew that if I had chosen not to be with my mother during her illness, I would probably have regretted it. It was going to be seismic, but I needed to go.

But that person‚Äôs voice. I do think about it. If I‚Äôm honest with myself, it dovetails with my own middle-of-the-night anxieties. Should I have stayed?

I lost the person I was with at the time, who I hoped I‚Äôd spend my life with. That loss was devastating; the move itself was devastating. I loved my old life. But in comparison to not being there when Ma was struggling?

So, no. I did the right thing, even if I suffered a loss in the process. I‚Äôm grateful I was able to spend that time with my family. I was able to take Ma for walks and sit around the dining room table and give her hugs at the end of the day and help her brush her teeth when she was too weak to get out of bed. I was there. I am glad I was there.

If you arrange your parenting for your convenience rather than their well-being, they‚Äôll feel it.

For example, I‚Äôve found that if I get up as soon as he falls asleep, and he wakes up twenty minutes later to find himself in a dark room by himself, he‚Äôs scared in the moment, but trust has been eroded over time. Yes, eventually he needs to sleep by himself, but also, he‚Äôs three years old. There‚Äôs time. And I did it enough times that he now asks me, plaintively: ‚Äúdo you promise you‚Äôll stay with me?‚Äù The first time he asked broke my heart.

I used to love traveling for work: when I was based in the Bay Area I‚Äôd go to New York City for long trips and love exploring in the cracks between commitments. I‚Äôd walk across the Brooklyn Bridge and find little shops in small corners; psychogeography the shit out of that place. And there would be all kinds of conversations I‚Äôd get to have as a result: meeting people for a coffee here, for a beer there.

But now I have a little guy who doesn‚Äôt understand why I‚Äôm going away, and who misses his daddy. It makes him nervous. He doesn‚Äôt FaceTime for long, but I‚Äôve been told he‚Äôs obviously depressed when I‚Äôm not around. I still love traveling, and as he gets older I‚Äôll find ways to bring him with me. But until then, I need to minimize the trips. I need to stay in bed and give him a hug. I need to spend the time.

When you set up high expectations and rigid rules, you‚Äôre not creating the conditions for a child to grow up into their own person. You‚Äôre effectively setting up a template and punishing them when they meander from it. Worse, you‚Äôre taking a still-developing human, who doesn‚Äôt understand their own emotions yet and hasn‚Äôt developed strong communication skills, and you‚Äôre ignoring the underlying needs and feelings that form the subtext of their behaviors. In a real way, you‚Äôre ignoring their humanity.

Having a child has taught me to look for the signs of sadness, of quiet worries, of not feeling well behind what a strict parent might call ‚Äúacting out‚Äù. Every time he throws something or ignores something I ask him to do, if I remember to pause and really ask him about it, I‚Äôll find that there‚Äôs something he isn‚Äôt saying ‚Äî or at least, not saying with words. We can usually have a good conversation about it, and then a hug. It builds trust. He knows I‚Äôm looking out for him. I see him.

And then, of course, there‚Äôs the parents who hit their children. That‚Äôs the version that‚Äôs unambiguous abuse. It‚Äôs a caveman approach to nurturing a human being that I think says a lot more about the emotional intelligence and capabilities of the parent than it does the child. They‚Äôll often justify it in weird ways, by saying things like, ‚ÄúI was smacked and it never hurt me.‚Äù There often seems to be a kind of defiance to it. But guess what? Not being smacked would have hurt you less. I bet pausing for a beat and digging into how they feel would be revealing, too.

Parenting is hard. It can try your patience. But I can‚Äôt imagine hitting my child and wanting him to be anything less than his own person, free from everybody‚Äôs templates and expectations. Part of keeping him safe is keeping him safe from anyone who would seek to subjugate his spirit. And if anyone ever tries to hit my kid, I‚Äôm calling the police.

When I‚Äôm stressed, or feeling under the weather, or having trouble thinking my way around a problem, I‚Äôve found that going for a walk is the best thing I can possibly do. It takes me out of my context, it allows me to blow off steam, and it puts me in a relatively isolated state where I have fewer distractions or inputs. It‚Äôs its own form of attention, in a way; its own way of being in the world.

It‚Äôs also really good exercise, particularly if you do it briskly: a 15 or 16 minute mile is a decent walking pace. As a bonus, it‚Äôs even better for blowing off steam at that speed.

My opinion: if you don‚Äôt live somewhere where you can walk outside easily, move.

My trauma therapist and I have a shorthand: she tells me to get that milkshake.

What it means is this: sometimes it‚Äôs important to go do something nice for yourself. You don‚Äôt need to ask permission; you can just do it.

Life can be a lot. And I happen to like milkshakes. So sometimes, quietly, when I need a treat, I go and get one, guilt-free.

I think they have a lot more going on than they let on, is all I‚Äôm saying.

Don‚Äôt believe me? Talk to one. It‚Äôll listen.

There used to be a cow field between my home and the center of town. I‚Äôd walk through it twice a day, stepping over the cattlegrid and dodging the cyclists who zoomed past. The cows were curious and friendly; they would come and investigate what you were up to.

There was another field that lay far below the Marston Ferry Road, back in Oxford, where I grew up. You could stand against the fence at the road and the cows would look up to see you. If you stayed there for long enough, they would congregate around you, as if you were the Pope. Perhaps they were hoping I‚Äôd feed them. I‚Äôd like to think they thought I might have something to say.

I‚Äôve made two major moves in my adult life: once to California, and once, after my mother died, away from California, to the area outside of Philadelphia. It was lonely.

To have a friendship ‚Äî a real one, not a warmed-up acquaintanceship ‚Äî is to have built a non-romantic relationship where you really see each other. Neither wants anything from the other; there are no romantic or sexual expectations, or really expectations of any kind except that you‚Äôll be there. It‚Äôs a relationship of shared support, values, and community.

Without it, you wither. People who don‚Äôt have friends die earlier. And while the internet can help you keep in touch with people you have moved away from, there‚Äôs no real alternative to having that mutual support there, with you, in the flesh.

But everybody moves. It‚Äôs not realistic to stay in the same place your whole life. People get jobs, family members get sick, people get priced out of their communities, there‚Äôs a Brexit. All kinds of things happen. So staying in one place is not a foolproof solution.

The thing, then, is to look for new places with community in mind. Where are you going to find like-minded people? Who are the people who see you now, and what kinds of places do they hang out in? Where are the comparable places in your new geography? Where are your people?

For me, that means finding the bookstores; the community spaces; the outsider arts events; the live music and the weird between-the-cracks culture. Find the people who don‚Äôt want to live to someone else‚Äôs template but do want to be kind. That‚Äôs where the good stuff is.

And given the choice between choosing a beautiful house in the middle nowhere and a lackluster apartment in a place where you have community, I‚Äôd pick the place with community. It‚Äôs going to make your life better. It‚Äôs going to make everything better. Community cuts to the core of what life is; a house is just a house.

My Oma taught me to cook. She loved to make food; often she‚Äôd be thinking about the evening meal throughout the entire day, regardless of whatever else was going on. In her nineties, she moved in with my parents, and although her love of cooking hadn‚Äôt diminished, her ability to stand over a stove had. So I helped her.

She was part-Indonesian, so the first dishes I put together started with spice mixes of turmeric, coriander, ginger, garlic, onion, and chillies. Indonesians call this the bumbu: a spice paste that can form the basis of many dishes.

You‚Äôre meant to make them with shallots, not onions. There‚Äôs supposed to be galangal rather than ginger; candlenuts are common. But those things weren‚Äôt easy to get in the San Joaquin Valley back then, so she made do. Sometimes she used milk instead of coconut milk; sometimes she couldn‚Äôt find ketcap manis. And it was always fantastic anyway.

You can improvise. You can use available ingredients. You can work with what you have and make the result your own, instead of trying for an unchanging perfect ideal. That‚Äôs how culture changes and ebbs and flows. I still make Indonesian meals, but they‚Äôre different to how my Oma did it, and the way I teach my son will be slightly different to how I learned. And so it goes, forever.

The important thing was the making and the eating, the gift of food and the sharing of it, not the verbatim copying of a version of a dish. There‚Äôs skill and craftsmanship in doing that, but that‚Äôs not where the life is.

One was made with love, which still shines through the recipe; by following the same path, even if you substitute some ingredients you‚Äôre making it with love again. The other is just a product. The ingredients have changed over time; the portions are slightly different for business reasons; it‚Äôs missing the context and the smells. It‚Äôs generally better to let those memories sit.

And post about it on the internet. Then, if something happens, people can point at your post, nod to themselves sagely, and say, ‚Äúhe died as he lived.‚Äù

I like the OK Go cover, for what it‚Äôs worth.

I remember taking my high school exams in the gym, individual chairs placed in rows atop wooden floors that smelled faintly of feet. You could hear breathing; the occasional cough; the squeak of rubber on hardwood as the invigilator roamed the aisles.

Showing your working was vital. Your answer to a math question could ultimately be wrong, but if your thinking was along the right lines, you‚Äôd pick up some points. They didn‚Äôt want to teach us by rote; they wanted to teach us how to navigate problems.

All of my best professional experiences have been derived from showing my working. When I started Elgg, every success was because we blogged how we were thinking about it; before we‚Äôd written a single line of code, before we knew we‚Äôd write any code, we‚Äôd talked about why it was important. People were attracted to the product, sure, but more than that, they were attracted to the ideas behind the project. And when we were wrong, they let us know ‚Äî kindly. It helped us learn and grow.

That principle has continued to this day: to, in fact, you reading these words right now. Every time I share how I think, I make connections that I might not have otherwise. It‚Äôs helped me build community, land jobs I never would have landed, and find myself in rooms that would otherwise have been closed off to me.

The more you share of who you are, how you think, what you care about, and what your skills are, the easier it is for other people to find you, and for you to build connections and relationships. That doesn‚Äôt mean put yourself at risk: I‚Äôm not about to publish my home address here or reveal precise details about my kid. But there‚Äôs a lot you can say about yourself if you work in the open.

In the early 2000s, a bunch of early web users, including me, wanted to tear down traditional gatekeepers: publishers who dictated whose voices could and couldn‚Äôt be heard, politicians who didn‚Äôt listen inclusively to communities, the traditional structures of power that maintained their own dominance, only including people who didn‚Äôt come from those hierarchies if they were deemed to be useful or compliant. So much of the early web movement was about creating a more participative world.

And then it turned out that some of those people saw an opportunity to insert themselves as gatekeepers. People like Mark Zuckerberg created vast companies that, in time, came to intermediate and charge rent for more than those old gatekeepers ever had. They sought to own aspects of our lives, like talking to our friends, that previously had been free from intermediation. The way for their companies to grow was to encroach upon the cultural commons. The gates they built became more and more powerful over time. As they calcified, some of them became templates that came to govern the rhythms and tenor of everybody‚Äôs lives.

Some did not. Others built the indieweb, and the free software movement, and found ways to undermine the control of these new gatekeepers. They stayed true to the values of the movement.

I tried to be one of them. Early in my career, I saw that ed-tech companies were milking giant contracts from tax-funded universities, while delivering software that didn‚Äôt do much to help people learn. Elgg was a direct response to this; it was fueled by a deep anger at the people who would seek to strip-mine a public good. Known, my second open source platform, was aimed directly at people like Zuckerberg. They were both attempts to undermine centralized wealth and power. That‚Äôs what drove me, and I have no regrets.

I have learned to look for the people who tear down gates for good, who try and foster new co-operative, participative movements in their place. They‚Äôre always there, even if they are not the most prominent voices in the room. And together, there‚Äôs a lot we can still do to make the world better.

Someone joining the movement for the wrong reasons doesn‚Äôt invalidate the movement. It just makes the work even more important.

Yeah, sure, read the ‚Äúgood‚Äù stuff. I love literary fiction. The Color Purple is my idea of a perfect novel. I just finished I Who Have Never Known Men, which is an astonishing novel that plumbs the depths of what it means to be human, written with poetry.

But you can read whatever you want. All inputs are worthwhile. Pulpy airport thrillers have brought me through some hard times. Fan fiction has struck a nerve that I never knew existed. Some of the most well-crafted writing I‚Äôve ever read was published on a style-free website, tumbling onto the page in 12-point Times New Roman. It‚Äôs all good. All of it.

If you want to write, the only imperative is to read.

That‚Äôs certainly true for my long-form writing, and that might be advice you‚Äôve read before. But it‚Äôs true for my short-form writing, too. If I haven‚Äôt dug into a book lately, my blogging suffers. Even my writing at work ‚Äî emails and process documentation are hardly the bastion of literary prowess at the best of times ‚Äî is less inspired.

‚ÄúThere are other fish in the sea,‚Äù the aphorism goes. But when you‚Äôre in a relationship where things aren‚Äôt going perfectly, I think it‚Äôs better to assume there aren‚Äôt.

I don‚Äôt mean that you should stay in an abusive or untenable situation. If you are being harmed and there‚Äôs no chance of living in harmony, then, absolutely, you need to get out of there. But if it‚Äôs just not quite right, or if circumstances have become obstacles, I think there‚Äôs a lot to be gained by fighting for it. At least until you‚Äôve determined that there‚Äôs no possible way forward.

This is where, in my life, not showing up for myself has sometimes allowed me to fall into a defeatism that has caused me to give up early. ‚ÄúOf course this won‚Äôt work,‚Äù I think to myself. I‚Äôm the through line to the failure. I shouldn‚Äôt assume that someone would want to be with me. They‚Äôll be better off without me.

The result is giving up on people who really care and situations that could last a lifetime. It‚Äôs not a given; nothing is. But there‚Äôs a real scarcity to people that are really compatible with you. (Or, I should say, there‚Äôs a real scarcity to people that are really compatible with me.) So, while it‚Äôs worked out for me in the end, I have sometimes wished I would have fought harder, and not assumed that eventually everyone will want someone better.

I don‚Äôt think you can show up well in a relationship without assuming it‚Äôs the only relationship on earth that will ever be important to you. It‚Äôs got to have fire. It‚Äôs got to have stakes.

And if you give up without fighting for it, it doesn‚Äôt.

Q: Why did Pierre-Joseph Proudhon only drink camomile tea?<br>
A: Because all proper tea is theft.

A single person holds many conflicting identities, roles, beliefs, and experiences; our selves are complex and ever-changing. There is no singular, static definition that we can use to capture any person.

We‚Äôre not making art or building a business, because there‚Äôs no way to separate the self cleanly into those categories. We‚Äôre not our professional titles and our personal contexts, because those things are inseparable. We have no way of surgically extracting pieces of ourselves, or freezing them and framing them, unchanged. We‚Äôre always learning, always growing, always making connections between the things we know, the things we‚Äôve felt, our flaws, our traumas, our successes, our pride, the things we‚Äôve done and haven‚Äôt done. In everything we do and everywhere we are, we are all of ourselves.

When we build walls, we build overhead, and we keep building overhead until it‚Äôs impossible to maintain and it all comes tumbling down. A single cave‚Äôs shadows can‚Äôt capture a whole person.

Better, then, to understand that we are our whole selves, and to respect that in ourselves and in the people around us. We are smart and brave and silly and stupid. We are strategic and impulsive. We must be allies for each other. In a world where we are asked to refine ourselves down into digestible metadata for the benefit of machines and algorithms, we must celebrate our full humanity.

Bring your full self to work. Bring your full self home. Only when we‚Äôre allowed to be intact, with a community built on mutual sight and support, can we live sustainably: our overheads manageable, our wounds tended to, our victories celebrated.

And we all deserve to live sustainably. We all deserve to be supported. We all deserve to be well. We all deserve to live with our full, changing, contradictory identities out in the open, unmasked.

title: Scientists Discover Impossible Object in Deep Space
description: "In fact, at first I was skeptical about the signal as it was too strong to be real."
fullText:
While peering into some of the oldest regions of the known universe ‚Äî dating back to just 1.4 billion years after the Big Bang ‚Äî an international team of astronomers made a puzzling discovery.

As detailed in a paper published the journal Nature, they discovered an extremely hot galaxy cluster that‚Äôs far hotter and older than current theories allow.

In other words, the discovered cluster is, under our current best understanding of cosmology, impossible ‚Äî which could upend our current understanding of how the early universe evolved.

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt expect to see such a hot cluster atmosphere so early in cosmic history,‚Äù said lead author and University of British Columbia PhD candidate Dazhi Zhou in a statement about the finding.

‚ÄúIn fact, at first I was skeptical about the signal as it was too strong to be real,‚Äù he added. ‚ÄúBut after months of verification, we‚Äôve confirmed this gas is at least five times hotter than predicted, and even hotter and more energetic than what we find in many present-day clusters.‚Äù

The astronomers‚Äô best theory is that the cluster somehow got a massive head start ‚Äî previously unimaginable even to top thinkers ‚Äî thanks to black holes lurking at its core.

‚ÄúThis tells us that something in the early universe, likely three recently discovered supermassive black holes in the cluster, were already pumping huge amounts of energy into the surroundings and shaping the young cluster,‚Äù added coauthor and Dalhousie University professor Scott Chapman, ‚Äúmuch earlier and more strongly than we thought.‚Äù

Conventional theories suggest that galaxy clusters gain energy as the gases inside are pulled together and squeezed due to intensifying gravitational forces. The latest research, however, suggests there‚Äôs more to how these clusters evolve ‚Äî perhaps even a separate source beyond these gravitational forces.

The team found the strange readings when they analyzed observations by the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in the Atacama desert in Chile that examined a ‚Äúbaby‚Äù galaxy cluster called SPT2349-56.

The cluster, which dates back to around 12 billion years, is huge: its core alone measures around half a million light-years across. That‚Äôs roughly the size of the halo that circles our own Milky Way galaxy, a vast region that contains globular clusters and older stars ‚Äî yet it spawns stars more than 5,000 times faster.

The astronomers are hoping to figure out what allowed it to get so incredibly hot, a source of energy that defies our current models. The research suggests galaxy clusters evolve in a far more explosive manner than previously thought, aided by gravitational interactions between multiple supermassive black holes.

‚ÄúWe want to figure out how the intense star formation, the active black holes and this overheated atmosphere interact, and what it tells us about how present galaxy clusters were built,‚Äù Zhou explained in the statement. ‚ÄúHow can all of this be happening at once in such a young, compact system?‚Äù

‚ÄúUnderstanding galaxy clusters is the key to understanding the biggest galaxies in the universe,‚Äù Chapman said. ‚ÄúThese massive galaxies mostly reside in clusters, and their evolution is heavily shaped by the very strong environment of the clusters as they form, including the intracluster medium.‚Äù

More on galaxy clusters: Scientists Intrigued by Bridge of Dark Matter Inside Huge Galaxy Cluster

title: Preschool Teacher, 22, Arrested on TV After Condemning Trump
description: A preschool teacher was arrested on camera as soon as she finished a TV interview criticizing Donald Trump, fueling the debate over protest policing and free speech. Jessica Plichta, 22, said she was the only person arrested among roughly 200 demonstrators at an anti-war protest in Grand Rapids, Michigan, on Saturday, hours after Nicolas Maduro was detained in Caracas by the U.S. military. In the broadcast footage, two officers could be seen approaching from behind as she wrapped her interview w
fullText:
A preschool teacher was arrested on camera as soon as she finished a TV interview criticizing Donald Trump, fueling the debate over protest policing and free speech.

Jessica Plichta, 22, said she was the only person arrested among roughly 200 demonstrators at an anti-war protest in Grand Rapids, Michigan, on Saturday, hours after Nicolas Maduro was detained in Caracas by the U.S. military.

In the broadcast footage, two officers could be seen approaching from behind as she wrapped her interview with WZZM, the city‚Äôs ABC affiliate, then escorted her away as she told them, ‚ÄúI am not resisting arrest.‚Äù

WZZM said an officer cited ‚Äúobstructing a roadway and failure to obey a lawful command,‚Äù and that Plichta had been charged with failure to obey a lawful command.

Plichta later told Zeteo: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a coincidence that as soon as I finished an interview speaking on Venezuela, I was arrested.‚Äù

She told the outlet the officers shoved her into the back of a patrol car without fastening her seat belt, then drove a short distance down the street‚Äîout of view of cameras and bystanders.

According to Plichta, they stopped again, pulled her out, bent her over the vehicle, patted her down, and took her belongings. She recalled one officer saying they moved her because she was ‚Äúmaking a scene.‚Äù

She also said officers repeatedly pressed her on whether she was Venezuelan, what her connection to Venezuela was, and why she had attended the protest. Plichta claimed they tried to get her to identify other demonstrators.

‚ÄúWe are so accustomed to, and used to, repression when we speak out on anti-war topics. When we speak out for Venezuela, when we speak out for Palestine, we expect the police to want to shut that down,‚Äù she told Zeteo.

‚ÄúIt just shows how much they feel they can get away with things, how easy it is for them to isolate people from the public eye when they‚Äôre doing this.‚Äù

Plichta said she largely stayed quiet as officers took her to jail, where she said the same questions continued. She was released about three hours later after other protesters gathered to demand she be freed and was seen punching the air in a video shared on Facebook.

The Grand Rapids Police Department disputed her claims in a statement to the Daily Beast.

A spokesperson said more than ‚Äú25 announcements were made from the PA system of a marked police cruiser for the group [of protesters] to leave the roadway and relocate their activities to the sidewalk,‚Äù but that they had ‚Äúrefused lawful orders‚Äù to move to the sidewalk and ‚Äúbegan blocking intersections.‚Äù

Adding that supervisors told officers they could arrest anyone who could be ‚Äúpositively identified,‚Äù the spokesperson confirmed only one arrest was made. The Beast followed up to ask why only Plichta had been arrested, but had not received a response at the time of publication.

The mayor of Grand Rapids is David LaGrand, a Democrat.

The incident came to light as Trump, 79, tries to sell the Maduro operation at home, despite signs of public unease.

A Reuters/Ipsos poll released Monday found about one in three Americans approve of the U.S. strike, while 72 percent worry the U.S. will become too involved.

It is also a small part of a much larger information war that has even seen Trump amplify mislabeled footage on Truth Social to claim mass celebrations after the Maduro capture‚Äîa video that fact-checkers traced to an unrelated 2024 protest.

title: CBS Goes on ICE Barbie Propaganda Tour After ‚Äò60 Minutes‚Äô Storm

title: Experts issue warning as US community sinks into oblivion: 'People aren't necessarily aware that this is happening'
description: Officials are exploring engineering solutions.
fullText:
A new report identified San Rafael, California, as the Bay Area's most vulnerable neighborhood to sea-level rise. Residents dealing with chronic flooding need climate resilience in their communities. The neighborhood is under threat of sinking as the bay continues to rise.

According to the San Francisco Chronicle, the Canal District is at risk.

The surrounding region has a soil foundation that fills former wetlands. Its topography causes the land to sink even as the ocean rises.

Per the Chronicle, "parts of eastern San Rafael have sunk by several feet." Over the last 25 years, sea levels have risen 3 inches. Experts expect 12 inches between the next 25 and 45 years.

The impacts are being felt by the Latino and working-class residents. High tides swamp patios and parking areas. Moisture seeps into homes, causing mold and mildew.

"People aren't necessarily aware that this is happening," noted Rita Mazariegos, a member of a community sea-level rise steering committee, per the Chronicle.

This rising water is a direct result of human activity.

It's brought on by burning coal, oil, or gas, creating planet-overheating pollution. As these energy sources warm the Earth, glaciers melt, and seawater expands.

Isolated weather events, like a high tide or a heavy rainstorm, are temporary shifts. Climate impacts are a long-term pattern of extreme weather.

Extreme weather, such as hurricanes and wildfires, has always existed. However, human-induced changes in the climate can exacerbate life-altering extreme weather.

Do you worry about having toxic forever chemicals in your home?

Click your choice to see results and speak your mind.

The San Rafael neighborhood's main exit roads would suffer from this sea-level rise. They could be permanently underwater by 2050, per the Chronicle.

There are many ways to protect these shorelines and cool the planet.

San Rafael is exploring engineering solutions. Some methods include elevating roadways, upgrading pump stations, and building levees.

Experts suggest innovating architecture in flood zones. One example of a redesign, per the Chronicle, is to "flood-proof on the first floor." Designing buildings to float, as successful models in the Netherlands do, is another consideration.

People can address critical climate issues and support local policies for clean energy. Using electric cars and appliances will reduce the pollution that causes rising tides.

Fair funding and organizations such as the Canal Alliance are developing communal builds. A pedestrian bridge and bayshore land investments will create a safer, drier future.

title: China buys more US soybeans, total purchases near 10 million tons
description: SINGAPORE/BEIJING, Jan 6 (Reuters) - China's state stockpiler Sinograin bought 10 U. soybean cargoes this week, ‚Äãthree traders told Reuters on Tuesday, as the world's top buyer ‚Äåcontinues purchasing from the United States following a late-October trade truce.
fullText:
SINGAPORE/BEIJING, Jan 6 (Reuters) - China's state stockpiler Sinograin bought 10 U.S. soybean cargoes this week, ‚Äãthree traders told Reuters on Tuesday, as the world's top buyer ‚Äåcontinues purchasing from the United States following a late-October trade truce.

The cargoes, totalling around 600,000 ‚Äåmetric tons, are for shipment between March and May, with overall U.S. soybean purchases now approaching 10 million tons, the traders said.

That represents over 80% of the 12 million metric tons that U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent ‚Å†said China pledged to ‚Äåbuy by the end of February.

"There were more U.S. cargoes bought by Sinograin and total purchases are very close to ‚Äç10 million tons," said one of the traders with direct knowledge of the deals. "We think China will buy couple of million tons more to meet the ‚Äãtarget."

China's buying has underpinned Chicago soybeans in recent weeks, helping the ‚Äåmarket end 2025 on a positive note, as the resumption of imports from the United States following a thaw in Beijing‚ÄìWashington relations has erased most of the losses incurred during the trade war.

Chicago soybeans were trading up 0.1% at $10.62 a bushel as of 1140 GMT on Tuesday.

Beijing has ‚Å†stepped up U.S. soybean purchases despite ‚Äãa domestic supply glut driven by record ‚ÄãSouth American arrivals and weak demand.

In December, Sinograin held three public auctions to make room for U.S. shipments amid ample ‚Äçdomestic supplies.

However, average ‚Å†prices and clearance rates fell in successive rounds, with only one-third of soybeans sold in the final auction, Reuters previously reported.

Traders had ‚Å†expected Sinograin to sell around 4 million metric tons in the auctions.

title: Charlie Munger once said you can ‚Äòease off the gas‚Äô when you reach this money milestone, and Mark Tilbury agrees
description: YouTube host Mark Tilbury agrees with Charlie Munger's advice for young Americans trying to build wealth.
fullText:
Moneywise and Yahoo Finance LLC may earn commission or revenue through links in the content below.

While joining the millionaire club may feel out of reach for many young Americans, the power of compounding can make it possible.

It‚Äôs simple: you invest a small sum of money each month into a low-cost index fund. When you earn dividends, you automatically reinvest those proceeds to buy more shares, and your returns grow over time.

But there‚Äôs a catch, says personal finance YouTuber Mark Tilbury: the magic only really happens after you‚Äôve invested your first $100,000.

Thanks to Jeff Bezos, you can now become a landlord for as little as $100 ‚Äî and no, you don't have to deal with tenants or fix freezers. Here's how

Dave Ramsey warns nearly 50% of Americans are making 1 big Social Security mistake ‚Äî here‚Äôs what it is and 3 simple steps to fix it ASAP

Get early access to privately-held AI companies with Fundrise Venture Capital for as little as $10. Join 350,000+ investors today

‚ÄúDon't worry about earning millions,‚Äù Tilbury said. ‚ÄúInstead, focus on the first $100,000 because, after that, your net worth will go crazy.‚Äù

But Tilbury wasn‚Äôt the first to note the significance of this milestone.

Billionaire investor Charlie Munger is often credited for popularizing the importance of the first $100,000, once describing it as ‚Äúa b‚Äî-, but you gotta do it‚Äù because ‚Äúafter that, you can ease off the gas a little bit.‚Äù

But hitting that $100,000 milestone is tough for young Americans today ‚Äî especially when you consider the increased cost of living and sky-high home prices. About 56% of Americans believe the cost of living is too high, according to a survey conducted by Politico last month (1).

While it might take you longer to reach this milestone than it did previous generations, it‚Äôs still worth pursuing.

Here‚Äôs why the first $100,000 is so important and how to reach it quickly.

After you hit $100,000, ‚Äúcompound interest stops being lame,‚Äù according to Tilbury. ‚ÄúGetting that chunk of money as fast as possible is the key. [...] Once you get to this point, it‚Äôs almost inevitable that you‚Äôll be wealthy if you just invest in a low-cost index fund.‚Äù

To get there, Tilbury suggests people follow what he calls the GROWTH method:

G: Gain control of your finances.

O: Optimize your tax management.

T: Tap into additional income streams.

Gaining control of your finances is crucial for achieving long-term financial stability and reaching your goals. And according to Tilbury, there‚Äôs only one way to gain control of your finances ‚Äî budgeting. Once you‚Äôve assessed your budget, there may even be ways you can shave off some unnecessary dollars and avoid unnecessary spending.

title: Hilton drops Minneapolis hotel over cancelled ICE bookings
description: Hilton Worldwide Holdings has removed from its system a Minneapolis hotel that has refused to accept the bookings of Immigration and Customs
fullText:
NEW YORK, Jan 6 (Reuters) - Hilton Worldwide Holdings has removed from its system a Minneapolis hotel that has refused to accept the bookings of Immigration and Customs Enforcement ‚Äãagents, the hotel operator said on Tuesday.

A Hampton Inn hotel, a Hilton brand, outside Minneapolis, ‚ÄåMinnesota, refused to accommodate ICE agents, the Department of Homeland Security said in a post on social media platform X on Monday.

The ‚ÄåTrump administration has increased the number of officers in the area after allegations of fraud involving Somali immigrants.

"We are taking immediate action to remove this hotel from our systems. Hilton is - and has always been - a welcoming place for all," the company said on X.

Amid mixed reactions online from consumers, with some calling for a ‚Å†boycott and others vowing to support Hilton, ‚Äåthe hotel operator is the latest U.S. company after Cracker Barrel to distance itself from moves that were criticized by the Trump administration and its base.

Hilton made ‚Äçits comments after a video was posted on X on Tuesday which suggested ICE agents were still being refused rooms at the Hampton Inn in Lakeview, after Hilton and the independent operator of the hotel apologized for an initial incident.

"A ‚Äãrecent video clearly raises concerns that they are not meeting our standards and values," Hilton said. In ‚Äåa previous statement, Hilton said the property was independently owned and operated.

DHS Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said the department welcomed Tuesday's move by Hilton.

"Discriminatory business practices targeting DHS and deliberately undermining federal law enforcement are unAmerican and have real business consequences,‚Äù she said in a statement on X.

Everpeak Hospitality, which runs the Hampton Inn, was not immediately available for comment on the video on Tuesday. It said on Monday it was ‚Å†in touch with the impacted guests to ensure they were ‚Äãaccommodated.

"We do not discriminate against any individuals or agencies and ‚Äãapologize to those impacted," it said on its website.

McLaughlin said on X that the agency has not heard from Everpeak Hospitality.

DHS had said on Monday that after ICE officers ‚Äçbooked rooms using official government ‚Å†emails and rates, a staff member at the Hampton Inn on January 2 canceled their reservations.

"We are not allowing any ICE or immigrant agents to stay at our property," read an email ‚Å†from the hotel posted on X by DHS.

Shares of the hotel operator rose 2.09% in afternoon trading, after being down 2.46% ‚Äåat close on Monday.

title: Brazil surpassing US as top beef producer, easing global supply squeeze
description: Brazil surpassed the U.S. as the world's top beef producer last year, according to market estimates, after the South American country
fullText:
BARRETOS, Brazil, Jan 7 (Reuters) - Brazil surpassed the U.S. as the world's top beef producer last year, according to market estimates, after the South American country beat output forecasts by hundreds of thousands of tons, easing a global supply squeeze and helping limit a surge in meat prices.

Brazil was already the biggest beef exporter, shipping meat worth almost $17 ‚Äãbillion in 2025, according to government trade data released on Tuesday. Beef production numbers are not due until February, but analysts have recently raised their estimates. Farmers have been sending more animals to ‚Äåslaughter, cashing in on high export demand from countries including China and the U.S., where low supply has pushed beef prices to record levels.

Elevated slaughter typically leads to a period of low output as producers hold back animals to breed and rebuild herds. But productivity gains in Brazil ‚Äåmay limit or even prevent a downturn, people in the industry say. They noted that farms have been inseminating cattle quicker, fattening them faster and slaughtering them younger.

"Ten years ago, the average age of cattle slaughtered in Brazil was five years," said Vinicius Barbosa, a commercial manager responsible for tens of thousands of cattle at the CMA feedlot in Barretos, about 260 miles (420 km) north of Sao Paulo. "Now it is 36 months and going rapidly to 24," he said.

Mauricio Nogueira, head of livestock consultancy Athenagro, said Brazilian beef production far surpassed his forecast in 2025. Output grew 4% for the year, where he had predicted a 2.7% drop. The increase of around 800,000 tons was about equal to total annual exports of ‚Å†Argentina, the world's No. 5 beef shipper.

Rabobank, which had expected Brazil's beef production ‚Äåto decline in 2025, now sees 0.5% growth to 12.5 million tons carcass weight equivalent. The U.S. Department of Agriculture in December raised its estimate for Brazilian beef output by 450,000 tons to 12.35 million tons.

If the official numbers confirm market estimates, 2025 will be the first year that Brazil's output will have surpassed U.S. production, which fell 3.9% ‚Äçto 11.8 million tons in 2025, according to USDA estimates, following years of drought.

FEEDLOTS, RISING CARCASS WEIGHT DRIVE OUTPUT

U.S. beef production will fall a further 0.9% to 11.7 million tons in 2026, the USDA said. In Brazil, the USDA and Rabobank project a decline in output, but Nogueira said rising productivity could actually boost Brazil's production by around 300,000 tons.

title: Ethereum‚Äôs staking queues have cleared and that changes the ETH trade
description: With queues cleared and staking yields near 3%, the ‚Äúsupply shock‚Äù narrative is fading even as Ethereum remains the largest DeFi base layer.
fullText:
Ethereum‚Äôs staking queues have emptied out and the network can now absorb new validators and exits almost in real time.

This means the rush to lock up ETH has faded for now and staking is settling into a steady-state instead of a scarcity trade.

Queues are simply the time spent to start or stop staking on the Ethereum network, acting as a sentiment gauge and a liquidity gauge.

In one sense, the lack of queues is a feature, not a bug, as these are proof Ethereum can handle staking flows without locking up liquidity for weeks.

At the same time, staking rewards have compressed toward 3% as total staked ETH grew faster than issuance and fee income, limiting incentives for renewed surges in either direction and leaving queues near zero even as overall staking participation remains elevated.

Lower yield can reflect crowding, but also a higher ‚Äòtrust premium‚Äô ‚Äî more ETH is choosing to sit in staking rather than on exchange order books.

What this means in plain terms is that ‚Äústaking pressure‚Äù is no longer a daily narrative.

When queues are long, ETH supply is effectively being locked faster than the network can onboard validators, and that can create a sense of scarcity.

When queues sit near zero, the system is closer to neutral. People can stake or unstake without waiting weeks, which makes staking feel less like a one-way door and more like a liquid allocation.

This changes the psychology around the ether trade.

Staking still reduces immediate sell pressure, but it is not the same as coins being stuck. With withdrawals functioning smoothly, ETH behaves less like a forced lockup asset and more like a yield-bearing position that can be resized when sentiment shifts.

Overall, Ethereum's staking supply is at around 30%, well below the 50% that Galaxy Digital predicted at the end of 2025. Expectations Galaxy had that ETH would sustain prices above $5,500 thanks to staking-induced supply shock, and that layer-2s would overtake layer-1s in economic activity, failed to materialize.

Ethereum‚Äôs DeFi TVL sits around $74 billion, well below its roughly $106 billion peak in 2021, even as daily active addresses have nearly doubled over the same period, according to DeFi Llama.

The network still accounts for close to 58% of total DeFi TVL, but that share masks a more fragmented reality.

Incremental growth is increasingly being captured by ecosystems such as Solana, Base, and bitcoin-native DeFi, allowing activity to expand across the Ethereum orbit without translating into the same concentration of value or demand for ETH itself.

title: Volkswagen and Porsche recall over 500,000 US vehicles
description: STORY: Problems with the rearview mirror have forced Porsche and now parent company Volkswagen to recall over half a million vehicles collectively in the US.The US National Highway Traffic Safety Administration announced the latest round of measures on Tuesday (January 6).VW Group of America, including its Audi subsidiary, is recalling over 356,000 vehicles in the country.The NHTSA said it's due to a software error that can lead to problems displaying the rearview camera image.VW recorded annual sales in the U.
