title: Chris Rigg Is Exactly Where He Needs To Be
description: ‚ÄúNow that he finds himself amid the bright lights of the Premier League, why shouldn‚Äôt he continue along the same path?‚Äù
fullText:
Want an illustration of how quickly time seems to pass by in football terms ‚Äî or simply graphic proof of how radically things have evolved at Sunderland in recent years?

The picture below was taken just under three years ago, during a game in which a ridiculously youthful Chris Rigg was denied what would‚Äôve been a fairytale FA Cup goal against Fulham at Craven Cottage and everyone started to sit up and take notice of the latest exciting talent to roll off the Academy of Light‚Äôs production line.

During the intervening three years, a hell of a lot has changed at the Stadium of Light.

Tony Mowbray was temporarily replaced by Mike Dodds, Michael Beale was hired and succeeded as head coach by Mike Dodds and then R√©gis Le Bris, and the entire process ‚Äî often difficult and frustrating ‚Äî eventually led to the promised land of Premier League promotion, with Rigg earning the right to call himself a top flight footballer after a red and white rise that‚Äôs encompassed memorable goals, eye-catching performances and plenty of excitement about what he could eventually achieve.

Of course, the dynamic is very different now and if the Sunderland side in which Rigg made his first team debut was talented if somewhat unbalanced and lacking depth in key areas, the team in which he‚Äôs currently fighting to establish himself in is of a far higher standard.

Under Le Bris, Sunderland are competitive in the Premier League and after a heavyweight summer recruitment drive, Rigg is now surrounded by elite talents in more or less every position. As such, the former prodigy is entering the next stage of his development ‚Äî one during which we all hope his rate of progress will continue.

I firmly believe that at this stage and for the good of his future prospects, Rigg is exactly where he needs to be.

It‚Äôs true that he‚Äôs often been played outside of his ‚Äúnatural‚Äù position and although he always gives his all when deployed on the wing, it‚Äôs obvious that his skillset is best suited to the number ten position, albeit with Enzo Le F√©e arguably our leading light in that particular role. That‚Äôs not necessarily problematic in itself ‚Äî this league demands far greater quality and depth, after all ‚Äî and for Rigg, perhaps it‚Äôll simply be a matter of patience, discipline and seeing the bigger picture.

Given that he comes across as a single-minded, grounded and extremely driven young footballer, one would hope that the presence of such talent within the Sunderland camp is inspiring Rigg, driving him on and ensuring he keeps his eyes on the goal of constant improvement.

In my view, one thing is absolutely certain: Rigg should not be loaned out this month and if we arrive at the end of the transfer window having bade a temporary farewell to this immensely talented prospect, it would be detrimental to his own personal development and would also deprive Sunderland of a valuable option; someone who could play an important role during the final months of the season.

Despite the impressive way in which we overhauled the squad during the summer, the long-standing argument of ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs not ready for the Premier League‚Äù is ringing increasingly hollow, as is the notion that we should send a gifted player to the Championship on the basis they need to ‚Äútoughen up‚Äù. In fact, it‚Äôs not too dissimilar to the stuff we used to hear as starry-eyed kids back in the Russell Foster days: ‚ÄúThis player or that player won‚Äôt make it because they‚Äôre too small‚Äù, and so on.

Such has been the explosion of talented teenagers in recent years that if you haven‚Äôt established yourself by the age of twenty or so, you‚Äôre viewed as being behind the curve, but that‚Äôs a red herring.

It‚Äôs a universal truth that different players develop at different rates, and the idea of such a quality footballer being farmed out and forced to mix it with the likes of Millwall and Stoke City on the basis that his development will be expedited as a result is fairly gruesome.

Rigg is currently training and playing within an elite, high-performance environment, with a coach and captain setting and driving high standards having implemented a style of football that demands a great deal from the squad.

To my mind, that‚Äôs the perfect place for him and I trust Le Bris and his coaching staff to continue to do the right thing ‚Äî and for Rigg himself to continue to apply himself properly and make the most of any and all opportunities that he‚Äôs given.

As was the case back in 2023, the sky is the limit for Rigg and now that he finds himself amid the bright lights of the Premier League, why shouldn‚Äôt he continue along the same path? It‚Äôs all within his hands and I‚Äôm hopeful that he‚Äôll do exactly that.

title: On This Day (7 January 1862) Sunderland‚Äôs First Captain, John Auld, Is Born
description: Captain of our first league team and a player of considerable skill and influence, Johnny Auld was a leader on and off the field and something of a football pioneer.
fullText:
John Robertson Auld was born in Scotland in 1862. His early football career appears to have been fashioned playing centre-half for Lugar Boswell, a club based in the small Ayrshire town of Lugar where he had moved to with his elder brother to open a Cordwainer‚Äôs (shoe-mender‚Äôs) business.

His determined and attacking performances brought him to the attention of famed Scottish side Third Lanark in 1883 and he seems to have played there for most of the period between 1883 to 1887, although there is record of him turning out for Queens Park during this period too. Both these clubs were within walking distance of his parents‚Äô home in Glasgow, and it seems he spent weekends there, returning to his work in Lugar during the week.

In 1887/88 he signed for Queens Park, where his play was described as ‚Äúa little rough‚Äù. He returned to play for Third Lanark in 1888/89 and it was in this season that the ‚ÄúThirds‚Äù or the ‚ÄúHi Hi‚Äù as they came to be known, won the Scottish Cup.

The winning of the trophy, as well as his three Scottish caps (two in 1887 and the other in 1889) all added to a burgeoning reputation for Auld in the game. He was an imposing centre-half who was adept at playing the more attacking Scottish version of his position and it was no surprise that clubs South of the border were showing interest.

In 1889 Tom Watson and Sunderland came North looking for talent. Top of their list was a captain and centre-half and Johnny Auld fitted the brief.

Sunderland were on the cusp of their first season in the Football League ‚Äì indeed, they were the first team to join the league after its formation in 1888/89. Stoke had finished bottom and had failed to get re-elected. Sunderland had mounted a vigorous campaign to be elected, including a promise to pay the travel costs of all visiting teams, a not inconsiderable burden given every other team in the league was from the North West or Midlands.

Johnny Auld was one of the first of a raft of heralded players recruited from Scotland by Sunderland in these early years of the league. Fine players such as Johnny Campbell and David Hannah from Renton, Hugh ‚ÄòLalty‚Äô Wilson from Newmilns and Jimmy Millar from Annbank were part of that first tranche of Scots to join Sunderland as ‚Äúthe team of all talents‚Äù began its formation.

Aged twenty-eight, Auld made the move South to join Tom Watson‚Äôs project. His transfer included an agreement by the club to facilitate the establishment of a Cordwainer‚Äôs business in the town. Auld also received a signing-on fee of ¬£20 and ¬£150 for agreeing to turn professional. He also negotiated a whopping ¬£300 in salary over two years. He was, without doubt, a major investment on the part of the club at this time, and his influence in attracting the best of talent North of the Border was probably part of the package he brought with him.

Sunderland finished a credible seventh in their first season and played their way to the semi-final of the FA Cup, with the capture of Ned Doig for ¬£150 from Arbroath a key acquisition as the spine of ‚Äòthe team of all talents‚Äô took life with Doig, Auld and Campbell/Millar.

The following season 1891/92 with the inspirational Auld as pivot and captain and the arrival of James ‚ÄúBlood‚Äù Hannah and Donald Gow from Glasgow Rangers, Sunderland won the league championship at only the second time of asking. It was a huge achievement and backed up by a colourful march to the FA Cup semi-finals again.

Auld‚Äôs influence and personality was a major factor in uniting and guiding these stars of the game into a team to be reckoned with.

The title was retained in 1892/93 and a runners-up spot in 1893/94, with the half-back line of Wilson, Auld and Gibson, with William Dunlop augmenting and eventually becoming a permanent member of this formidable line from 1892.

In 1894/95 the title was won again but by this point Johnny Auld was into his thirties and played only four games in the league campaign as he covered illness and injury in the half-back line. One game Johnny Auld did play in saw him captain the side and become the ‚ÄòWorld Champions‚Äô. Hearts, league champions in Scotland took on the English champions Sunderland on the 27th April 1895. Both teams were fully composed of Scottish players and a cracker of a game saw Sunderland and Johnny Auld lift the trophy, as they eventually triumphed by five goals to three, with Auld scoring one of the goals.

In 1896 Johnny Auld made the short but historic journey to Newcastle, becoming the first ever player to make that switch in the football league era. He only played a season before establishing a role that in its description resembles the modern day Sporting Director.

He became part of a three-man committee identifying players. His fame and influence were such that, similar to his time at Sunderland, a raft of good Scottish talent was signed. He was also instrumental in recruiting the innovative Scottish trainer John Quar McPherson. Consequently, by 1912, our closest rivals had three league titles and four FA Cup final defeats on their CV, eventually winning the cup in 1910.

Throughout his time at Newcastle Johnny Auld continued to reside in Sunderland and oversee his Cordwainers business in the town.¬†And, despite his role north of the Tyne, Auld still remained a key person in the story of Sunderland AFC. He acted as a financial guarantor for the club as Sunderland fell on hard times during the First World War, and also paid for the funeral of his former teammate Johnny Campbell in 1906.

Auld was residing at 46 Roker Park Road in the town when he passed away after a fall from a tram at the age of seventy in 1932. He is buried in Mere Knolls cemetery in Sunderland.

Johnny Auld was without doubt one of football‚Äôs first pioneers as a player. A captain and leader, his influence and skill, not only in defence but in the initiating of attacks at which he so excelled saw unprecedented success for the ‚Äòteam of all talents‚Äô and rightly affords him a place in the history of Sunderland AFC.

title: Match Preview: Brentford v Sunderland ‚Äî Clash Of The Surprise Packages!
description: Can we come out on top in a clash of this season‚Äôs surprise packages in the Premier League?
fullText:
TV/Stream: Full live match coverage is available via Sky Sports.

Radio: Full live match commentary available via BBC Radio Newcastle (not online)

Don‚Äôt forget to follow the blow-by-blow account of the game on the Roker Report Twitter feed (@RokerReport) and check out the player ratings after the full-time whistle at www.RokerReport.sbnation.com!

It‚Äôs the meeting of the two surprise packages of this season‚Äôs Premier League and it‚Äôs a tough test for the Lads tonight.

We‚Äôre shouting it from the rooftops that we‚Äôve remained unbeaten at home in the first half of the season and what an achievement that is from Le Bris‚Äô side, but even though they‚Äôve lost one, Brentford have taken one more point on home soil in the same number of games.

Only the top three have taken more points on their own patch and we have to look back to the 5th October for Keith Andrews‚Äô side last defeat at Griffin Park. Their away form isn‚Äôt nearly as good, which is another sign of how impressive this record is since they sit on thirty points as they occupy seventh in the table ‚Äì only ahead of us on goal difference.

Everyone thought the bubble had burst when Thomas Frank left to take the Spurs job, but Andrews has defied all of the predictions, although the pressure is firmly on holding their form at hom,e as only the bottom four have lost more than Brentford.

In all competitions, we‚Äôve only taken on tonight‚Äôs opposition on twenty occasions. In the forty years between meetings in the league that ranged from 1947 and 1987, we took them on twice, once in the FA Cup and once in the League Cup and this is only our fourth trip to Griffin Park for a league game in the last forty years ‚Äì the first in the top flight since 1946.

In the last four games, Le Bris‚Äô side has shown how hard we are to beat; tonight we may need a similar performance.

The bookies have the Lads at 16/5 to win the game, while Brentford are priced at 4/5, and the draw is 5/2.

title: High school boys basketball: Skyridge races past Layton in high-paced game
description: Skyridge came back to beat Layton 67-56, with double-digit points from four different seniors.
fullText:
The two halves of Tuesday‚Äôs game between Layton and Skyridge couldn‚Äôt have been more different, and they showed off two completely different styles of play.

Layton‚Äôs slow, defensive style dictated the first half, and the Lancers built up a lead. However, Skyridge‚Äôs fast-paced offense ruled supreme after halftime, and the Falcons ran away with the game 67-56.

The Lancers imposed their will first. It started on the defensive side of the ball as Layton built a quick 9-2 lead.

Layton held Skyridge to only 22 points in the first half and minimized the Falcons‚Äô strong suit, which is transition points. Rebounds and limiting turnovers also played into Layton‚Äôs hand and earned it a 29-22 halftime lead.

Skyridge‚Äôs Ryder Gentry kept the offense afloat by scoring 10 of the Falcons‚Äô 12 second-quarter points.

‚ÄúA lot of (the struggle) was because of Layton,‚Äù said Skyridge head coach Jeff Gardner. ‚ÄúCoach (Kelby) Miller runs one of the top programs in the state, and they came out and played really well and had us on our heels. They were really hard to score on. They blocked shots, and I felt like Layton really played well, but we made sure to just stay in the game, hanging around.‚Äù

The final 16 minutes couldn‚Äôt have looked much different from the first 16, and it all started in transition. Skyridge completely flipped the game‚Äôs pace by pushing the ball quickly after rebounds.

Skyridge then took that opportunity to work the ball around and get open shots on the perimeter that it didn‚Äôt get in the first half. The Falcons‚Äô Carson Mosteller hit two 3-pointers in the third quarter, with Zach Gagon and Gentry each adding another.

The quick pace and open shots led to a 20-4 run in the third quarter. In total, Skyridge outscored Layton 25-7.

‚ÄúWe wanted to keep the pace, and we wanted to keep attacking the rim,‚Äù Gardner said. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt do a great job in the first half finishing at the rim, but we felt like if we kept attacking the rim, it would open up our threes.‚Äù

Layton was down, but it certainly wasn‚Äôt out. The Lancers‚Äô Karter Miller hit two 3-pointers, including a four-point play, to try to stay in it.

That fight back wasn‚Äôt in the cards for Layton as Skyridge kept making strong basketball plays. Gentry ended with a team-high 19 points, but he also contributed game-winning plays like offensive rebounds and smart extra passes on offense.

‚ÄúI love that we can come back from a rough first half and play an amazing second half, turn it around, win by 10 when we were down by 10,‚Äù Gentry said. ‚ÄúI feel like that just shows that we have really good fight in us and we‚Äôre a great team.‚Äù

The senior core of Gentry, Gagon, Mosteller and Joel Gardner each contributed double-digit points in the comeback win, which was the fourth consecutive for the Falcons.

‚ÄúOur team likes to play fast, and we‚Äôve got this group of seniors who have been together since second grade, and they love to play with each other, and they believe in each other,‚Äù Gardner said. ‚ÄúI think just offensively, our whole message is attack the basket and then kick out when you can‚Äôt get to the rim. They did that masterfully.‚Äù

title: Wisconsin beats UCLA 80-72 in Bruins‚Äô first game in Madison since 1962
description: The Badgers shot 54% overall in the first half and made 8 of 16 from beyond the arc.
fullText:
MADISON, Wis. ‚Äî Nolan Winter and Nick Boyd combined for 23 first-half points, and Wisconsin jumped out early to beat UCLA 80-72 on Tuesday night.

Winter scored 12 points, and Boyd added 11 to help Wisconsin build a 45-31 halftime lead. The Badgers shot 54% overall in the first half and made 8 of 16 from beyond the arc.

In the second half, Winter‚Äôs two free throws stretched the Badgers‚Äô lead to 56-39. UCLA answered with a 17-7 run, capped by a Trent Perry 3-pointer to cut its deficit to 63-56 with 8:41 left, but the Bruins didn‚Äôt get closer.

Boyd finished with 20 points and Winter scored 18, and the pair each grabbed eight of the Badgers‚Äô 32 rebounds. John Blackwell added 17 points, and Andrew Rohde chipped in with 12 for Wisconsin (10-5, 2-2 Big Ten), which bounced back from an 89-73 loss at home on Saturday to fifth-ranked Purdue.

Eric Dailey Jr. scored 18 points on 9-of-17 shooting to lead UCLA (10-5, 2-2 Big Ten), which has lost back-to-back games for the first time this season. Tyler Bilodeau scored 16 points, and Perry added 15. The Bruins shot 46% from the field but missed 16 of their 17 3-point shots and were 15 of 23 from the free-throw line.

It was UCLA‚Äôs first game in Madison since Dec. 22, 1962.

UCLA: Hosts Maryland on Saturday.

Wisconsin: At second-ranked Michigan on Saturday.

title: Wennberg has goal and assist against former team as Sharks beat Blue Jackets 5-2
description: Alex Wennberg had a goal and an assist against his former team, and the San Jose Sharks bounced back from a frustrating loss three days earlier and beat the Columbus Blue Jackets 5-2 on Tuesday night.  Zack Ostapchuk also had a goal while Macklin Celebrini and Mario Ferraro added empty-netters to help the Sharks win their fourth in five games.  Alex Nedeljkovic stopped 34 shots for San Jose, which was coming off a 7-3 loss to Tampa Bay on Saturday night.
fullText:
SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP) ‚Äî Alex Wennberg had a goal and an assist against his former team, and the San Jose Sharks bounced back from a frustrating loss three days earlier and beat the Columbus Blue Jackets 5-2 on Tuesday night.

Zack Ostapchuk also had a goal while Macklin Celebrini and Mario Ferraro added empty-netters to help the Sharks win their fourth in five games. Alex Nedeljkovic stopped 34 shots for San Jose, which was coming off a 7-3 loss to Tampa Bay on Saturday night.

Wennberg, the Blue Jackets‚Äô first-round pick in 2013, assisted on Pavol Regenda‚Äôs goal in the first period then scored on a power play early in the second for his eighth goal of the season. That moved the 31-year-old within two points of reaching 400 for his career.

Celebrini‚Äôs goal was his 23rd of the season and extended the 19-year-old‚Äôs career-high point streak to 11 games.

Zach Werenski scored his team-leading 16th goal for Columbus, and Sean Monahan also had a goal. Jet Greaves finished with 31 saves.

San Jose broke through moments after Nedeljkovic stopped Charlie Coyle‚Äôs wrist shot. Regenda responded quickly and broke free to score his sixth of the season on a cross-ice pass from Wennberg with 49 seconds left.

Wennberg made it 2-0 with a power-play goal at 4:14 of the second when he fired the puck between Greaves' legs. It gave Wennberg his seventh multi-point game of the season.

Werenski trimmed San Jose‚Äôs lead to 2-1 with his goal late in the second. He has five points in three games since returning from an ankle injury.

Ostapchuk‚Äôs second goal of the season made it 3-1 before Monahan pulled the Blue Jackets within one with 3:55 to go.

Ferraro and Celebrini scored into the empty net 45 seconds apart to seal San Jose's win.

Blue Jackets: At Vegas on Thursday night.

Sharks: At Los Angeles on Wednesday night.

title: USC's lack of offensive discipline leads to fourth quarter eruption against Oregon Ducks
description: LOS ANGELES -- Coming off the heels of a 34-point loss to crosstown rival UCLA, the USC Women of Troy looked to etch a positive note in their first game back at the Galen Center in 2026 against the Oregon Ducks Tuesday night, but had, arguably, suffered an even greater loss.
fullText:
LOS ANGELES -- Coming off the heels of a 34-point loss to crosstown rival UCLA, the USC Women of Troy looked to etch a positive note in their first game back at the Galen Center in 2026 against the Oregon Ducks Tuesday night, but had, arguably, suffered an even greater loss. A contest that was surely in their hands from the jump, slipped away in a matter of minutes as the Ducks rallied back down by 16 points at the half and conjured up a 14-0 run to end the game, coming away with the 71-66 comeback win.

Following the stunning turn of events for USC, Head Coach Lindsay Gottlieb gave credit where it was due to Oregon.

‚ÄúCredit to Oregon. They were poised. I‚Äôm not surprised they hung in there when they were down‚Ä¶ about as upsetting a loss as we‚Äôve had in this building. We have a lot of potential to be really good, but not if we don‚Äôt figure some things out," coach Gottlieb said.

Before tip-off, USC had announced that defensive guru Kennedy Smith would be out Tuesday with a lower leg injury and listed as day-to-day. The absence of Smith was not felt until later down the stretch for the Women of Troy.

USC got off to a slow start offensively to begin the contest, mirroring their style of play at the Pauley Pavilion last Saturday, unable to score within the first four minutes of the game. The tides soothed for the Trojans as they would conclude the first quarter on an impressive 16-0 run, led by Kara Dunn's team-high 12 first-quarter points, and take a 23-9 lead to the second quarter.

The offensive production continued for the Women of Troy heading into the half, as Jazzy Davidson began her impressive performance on the floor, and by the end of regulation, notched the third double-double of her collegiate career with a final stat line of 14 points, 13 rebounds, 5 assists, 2 blocks, and two steals. Kara Dunn would lead the team with 21 points, but was more focused on the team's headspace and how they could improve on it moving forward, especially after back-to-back demoralizing losses.

"I think it's time that we make a change," Dunn said. "Coming off a loss like that, we need to be as hungry as we can be, and going into the next game, we have to have a change of heart."

Coach Gottlieb then voiced her view on the current status of her team's headspace and gave a clear reality check on what she saw shift from her team's first-half performance play, compared to the second half, which echoed through the media room in a frenzy.

"I thought we came out in the second half like we have arrived," coach Gottlieb said. "That's why I called such a quick timeout in the third quarter because I did not like our demeanor. I did not like how it felt. I felt we weren't pressuring them as much."

The headspace has to change for the Women of Troy as they gave up 50 second-half points to the Ducks, including the 14-0 run that Oregon would eventually go on in the final four minutes of the fourth quarter that inevitably decided the Trojans' fate.

With back-to-back losses like this, it would be hard to find the big red reset button needed as the new year gets going, but the Women of Troy have a few days to clear their head of their worst losses of the season before traveling to Minnesota on Sunday.

title: Ejiofor has 18, St. John‚Äôs defeats Butler 84-70
description: Ejiofor also contributed five rebounds and three steals for the Red Storm.
fullText:
INDIANAPOLIS ‚Äî Zuby Ejiofor‚Äôs 18 points helped St. John‚Äôs defeat Butler 84-70 on Tuesday.

Ejiofor also contributed five rebounds and three steals for the Red Storm (10-5, 3-1 Big East Conference). Bryce Hopkins went 7 of 12 from the field to add 17 points. Oziyah Sellers went 5 of 11 from the field to finish with 10 points.

Finley Bizjack led the Bulldogs (10-6, 1-4) in scoring, finishing with 21 points. Michael Ajayi added 14 points, nine rebounds and five assists for Butler. Evan Haywood recorded 11 points and two steals.

St. John‚Äôs entered halftime tied with Butler 42-42. Hopkins scored 15 points in the second half to help lead the way as St. John‚Äôs went on to secure a victory, outscoring Butler by 14 points in the second half.

title: New Berlin holds off Pawnee in Blake Lucas' return to Saltyville
description: New Berlin's offense went cold in the middle quarters, but Gabe Molloy helps Pretzels conquer Pawnee in coach Blake Lucas' return.
fullText:
NEW BERLIN ‚Äî Before the game, New Berlin junior Reid Hepperly, the last¬†player¬†introduced at the Pretzel Arena, went over and gave Pawnee coach Blake Lucas a handshake, then¬†gave him a meaningful, sincere¬†tap on the chest.

In the first quarter,¬†Hepperly¬†put on a display for his former coach by using his big body to¬†worm¬†his way in the paint and give the Pretzels¬†(11-4 overall)¬†eight points in the opening quarter. He finished the game with 16 points and 10 rebounds to help New Berlin and first-year coach Neil Holderread beat Pawnee 42-39 in a nonconference game and spoil Lucas‚Äô return to the school where he coached for¬†nine seasons and had a 165-102 record, plus two regional titles.

‚ÄúAs a coach, he was good,‚Äù Hepperly¬†said of¬†Lucas.¬†‚ÄúHe pushed us¬†real¬†hard.¬†Playing against him just gives us extra motivation.¬†Losing a coach, I mean, it sucks, but playing hard to beat him, it just felt good.‚Äù

Hepperly said he was¬†hyped¬†for the game all day.

‚ÄúI was ready to go.¬†All day at school, I was just waiting,‚Äù Hepperly said. ‚ÄúAnd then I came out here and did my best.‚Äù

More: Bailey Leach, Plains girls basketball sink SHS comeback | Top performers

Despite Lucas‚Äô prompt return to the school, it was his first time coaching in the Pretzel Arena, which opened this school year to replace the Pretzel Dome as the Pretzels‚Äô home¬†gym.¬†Lucas¬†mostly¬†dodged answering¬†questions about his return.

‚ÄúYou¬†coach¬†a group for several years and now you coach somewhere else,‚Äù he said.¬†‚ÄúGod protects us.¬†I'm¬†thankful to be in Pawnee.‚Äù

About the new gym, he said, ‚ÄúIt's¬†a nice gym.‚Äù

Gabe¬†Molloy, one of two New Berlin seniors, had back-to-back layups to start the fourth quarter and pull the Pretzels into a 33-33 tie with 6 minutes, 58 seconds left. After a¬†nearly¬†two-minute¬†lull in the scoring, Hepperly‚Äôs layup with 4:39 left gave New Berlin the lead for good.

‚ÄúGabe's a really good player,‚Äù Holderread said.¬†‚ÄúHe sets the tone¬†defensively,¬†he gets everything organized offensively.¬†Things that¬†don't¬†show up in the stat sheet all the time.

‚ÄúHe's¬†not scoring a ton of¬†points, (but)¬†he's¬†knocking down free throws when he needs to,¬†he's¬†getting us easy bucket after easy bucket.¬†Gabe is a luxury to have, for sure.‚Äù

It was certainly a turnaround from how cold the Pretzels were in the second and third quarters. New Berlin began the game with a 14-9 lead after the first¬†quarter but¬†struggled to score in the middle periods: 3-for-16 in the second and 2-for-8 in the third. That allowed Pawnee¬†(5-9)¬†to¬†establish¬†its game and take a¬†28-21 lead before Carson Dodd connected¬†on¬†a 3-pointer with 3:21 left in the third. Ty¬†Lederbrand, who was in foul trouble for most of the first half, scored in the paint and connected¬†on¬†a corner¬†3¬†for five quick points in the middle of that Pawnee run.

New Berlin¬†didn‚Äôt¬†want to lose twice to Pawnee in less than two weeks. Pawnee beat the Pretzels 47-35 in the first round of the Waverly Holiday Tournament¬†on¬†Dec. 26.

‚ÄúLast week we attacked their pressure and tonight, we just played a little hesitant,‚Äù Lucas said.¬†‚ÄúBecause of that,¬†we're¬†on the other side of the win-loss column.‚Äù

Sophomore Gavin Greer led Pawnee with 15 points while Ryder Smith finished with 10. Pawnee shot 16-for-37 overall, including two of seven in the fourth. Pawnee was also outrebounded on the offensive glass 12-4 (New Berlin had a 30-26 rebounding edge overall).

‚ÄúWe told our kids you can't expect just to come in and play the same way and expect the same result,‚Äù Lucas said.¬†‚ÄúYou've got to bring it.¬†Tonight was different: a¬†little bit lesser stage here in the regular season where Waverly is about as good as it gets besides the postseason.¬†We told our kids you had to come and even play better than you did.¬†We just missed some free throws (2-for-8) and¬†didn't¬†rebound well enough to win tonight.‚Äù

With 3:13 remaining, Max Pointer hit a transition layup for a 37-33¬†lead¬†and Hepperly followed that with a layup 49 seconds later.

‚ÄúHe's a big body,‚Äù Holderread¬†said of¬†Hepperly.¬†‚ÄúHe can do a lot of things for us.¬†He's¬†good on the boards,¬†he's¬†good in the post, he can shoot the 3.

‚ÄúHe's a tough matchup for any team that we play.¬†When¬†he's¬†able to do that early in the game, it¬†kind of¬†sets¬†the tone for the rest of us, and we take advantage of that.‚Äù

More: North Mac boys basketball soaks up elusive Waverly Holiday title

Lederbrand¬†then snapped the Pawnee scoring drought that lasted 7:02, from¬†a Randy¬†Schutt 3¬†with 1:16 left in the third until the layup by¬†Lederbrand¬†with 2:14 left in regulation. Jace¬†Jankousky¬†and Smith then split a pair of free throws to pull Pawnee within¬†39-37 with 1:10 left.¬†Molloy¬†had the final New Berlin field goal for a 41-37¬†lead¬†and Greer hit a turnaround fadeaway shot with 26 seconds left.¬†Pawnee‚Äôs hopes¬†were ended¬†on a turnover that became a jump ball to New Berlin with 2.4¬†remaining.

‚ÄúWe're a veteran group,‚Äù¬†Dodd¬†said.¬†‚ÄúWe have a lot of seniors and juniors, too, that stepped up this year.¬†We practice¬†hard,¬†we know what¬†we're¬†doing in that situation; we were prepared.‚Äù

Holderread reiterated¬†Dodd‚Äôs sentiment.

‚ÄúWe are veterans, but we're continuing to learn,‚Äù Holderread said.¬†‚ÄúThat's our goal.¬†We want to get better every single day.¬†That's¬†what¬†we're¬†trying to do.

‚ÄúI¬†actually mentioned¬†that at the end of the game here.¬†We've¬†kind of reversed¬†roles.¬†At the beginning of the season, it was me talking about how¬†we're¬†a veteran team, and we need to be able to close games when we lost a couple in the fourth quarter.

‚ÄúNow¬†it's¬†the opposite.¬†We're¬†doing those things where we have a lull in the middle of the game, and¬†we're¬†smart enough and veteran enough to make the right plays at the right time."

Contact Ryan Mahan: 788-1546,¬†ryan.mahan@sj-r.com, Twitter.com/RyanMahanSJR.

title: Kobe Bufkin, named after Kobe Bryant, drops 27 for South Bay Lakers
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif.
fullText:
EL SEGUNDO, Calif. ‚Äî The rise of another young star on the South Bay Lakers is grooming right in front of our eyes once again.

Meanwhile, down in Southbay‚Ä¶

Kobe Bufkin w/ another:

27 pts | 8 reb | 8 ast | 4 stls | 2 blks pic.twitter.com/Po1vn6zXEr

‚Äî Lakers Legacy (@LakersLegacyPod) January 7, 2026

If history has taught us anything, it‚Äôs that South Bay is more than just a G League stop‚Äîit‚Äôs a proving ground. Alex Caruso carved his path here. Austin Reaves refined his game here. Scottie Pippen Jr. rebuilt momentum here. Time and time again, the South Bay Lakers have developed players who either make it back to the NBA or force an NBA team‚Äôs hand.

Kobe Bufkin looks like the next name on that list.

Bufkin poured in 27 points to lead South Bay to a 113‚Äì101 win over the Memphis Hustle, putting together another all-around performance that continues to turn heads around the league. At just 22 years old, Bufkin is playing with the confidence, poise, and edge of someone who knows this opportunity won‚Äôt last forever.

Drafted 15th overall by the Atlanta Hawks in 2023 out of Michigan, Bufkin entered the league with high expectations. But as is often the case with young guards, things didn‚Äôt pan out the way either side envisioned early on. A new chapter opened on November 13, 2025, when Bufkin was traded from the Motor City Cruise, Detroit‚Äôs G League affiliate, and landed in South Bay.

There‚Äôs a certain poetry to it.

Bufkin was named after the late, great Kobe Bryant, and now finds himself wearing purple and gold in the organization most synonymous with the Mamba legacy.

‚ÄúKobe is my favorite player,‚Äù Bufkin said. ‚ÄúJust seeing his name on the wall, his pictures of him, it‚Äôs cool.‚Äù

That connection isn‚Äôt just symbolic. Bufkin often laces up Kobe Bryant signature shoes, occasionally switching to Jayson Tatum‚Äôs JT line, but the influence is clear in the way he plays‚Äîfearless, aggressive, and relentlessly competitive.

Jack Haslett -- The Sporting Tribune

South Bay Lakers guard Kobe Bufkin (6) waits for his teammates to help him up during a G-League basketball game between the South Bay Lakers and Memphis Hustle Tuesday, January 6, 2026 at UCLA Health Training Center in El Segendo, Calif.

Since arriving in South Bay, Bufkin has been lighting up the scoreboard, averaging 28.3 points, 5.0 assists, and 4.3 rebounds through his first four regular-season games. Against Memphis, he set the tone early.

Bufkin scored 10 points in the first quarter, igniting a Lakers offense that jumped out to a double-digit lead and stretched it to as many as 15 points in the first half. Every time the Hustle tried to close the gap, Bufkin answered.

The defining sequence came late in the third quarter. Bufkin took an offensive foul on a moving screen, popped right back up, demanded the ball, attacked the lane, floated in a tough finish, absorbed contact, and calmly knocked down the free throw to complete the three-point play for his 20th point of the night. It was a sequence that embodied his mindset‚Äîtoughness, urgency, and zero hesitation.

Bufkin finished with 27 points, eight rebounds, and eight assists in 39 minutes, stuffing the stat sheet while controlling the game‚Äôs biggest moments.

‚ÄúTaking advantage of that, getting my teammates involved,‚Äù Bufkin said. ‚ÄúWhen they weren‚Äôt down there protecting the rim, I‚Äôm taking it to the rim and making shots.‚Äù

The backcourt pairing of Bufkin and RJ Davis proved overwhelming for Memphis. Davis controlled the pace, organized the offense, and complemented Bufkin‚Äôs scoring punch, finishing with 17 points. Together, they kept the Hustle off balance all night.

South Bay also received strong contributions across the board. Anton Watson scored 18 points, Tevian Jones added 14, and Kylor Kelley chipped in 13, as all five starters finished in double figures. Off the bench, Arthur Kaluma provided an immediate spark, scoring nine points in the first quarter alone and finishing with 16 points, knocking down all three of his attempts from beyond the arc.

Despite committing 28 turnovers, the Lakers found ways to score, shooting an impressive 16-for-35 (45.7%) from three-point range and building a lead that grew to 16 points in the second half. Defensively, South Bay protected the paint, swatting away 14 shots in the win.

‚ÄúSomething me and RJ gotta talk about,‚Äù Bufkin said of the turnovers. ‚ÄúSlowing down, getting to our reads‚Äîbut yeah, that‚Äôs on us.‚Äù

Even in victory, accountability remains part of Bufkin‚Äôs approach‚Äîanother trait reminiscent of the name stitched across his chest.

South Bay now heads to Austin, Texas for a two-game road trip before returning home to host the San Diego Clippers on January 14. If Bufkin continues on this trajectory, it won‚Äôt be long before NBA teams start circling once again.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been a lot of things that I‚Äôve seen around the league, learning to keep your head down and keep working,‚Äù Bufkin said on the noise surrounding his name around the league.

Another Kobe is rising in South Bay‚Äîand this one looks ready for his next shot.

title: Fulham vs. Chelsea, Premier League: Preview, team news, how to watch
description: Calum McFarlane‚Äôs Blue and White Army
fullText:
Chelsea‚Äôs new head coach, Liam Rosenior is expected to be in attendance but will not leading the team just yet as the Blues make the short trip down the road to Craven Cottage, to take on friendly rivals Fulham. Instead of Rosenior, it will be interim head coach Calum McFarlane calling the shots, and hopefully just as effectively as he did over the weekend, when he engineered a very credible 1-1 draw away against Manchester City.

Alas, the only team to truly benefit from that draw were Arsenal, who now have a six point lead at the top of the table, just past the halfway mark of the season.

For Chelsea, it‚Äôs now just one win in our last eight Premier League matches, collecting just eight points from the 24 on offer. Somehow we‚Äôre still in fifth, but we‚Äôre going to have to start picking up points if we want to remain in the Champions League places by season‚Äôs end.

Date / Time: Wednesday, January 7, 19.30 GMT; 2:30pm EST; 1am IST (next day)
Venue: Craven Cottage, SW6
Referee: Peter Bankes (on pitch); John Brooks (VAR)
Forecast: Partly sunny and a slight breeze; no more snow sadly

On TV: Sky Sports Football (UK); none (USA); Star Sports Select HD2 (India); none (NGA); elsewhere
Streaming: Sky Go (UK); Peacock (USA); JioHotstar (India); DStv Now, SuperSport GOtv (NGA)

Fulham team news: It‚Äôs been a decent festive period for midtable (as usual) Fulham, getting draws against Liverpool and Crystal Palace and wins against West Ham and Nottingham Forest. Their draw against Liverpool, last time out, saw both teams score in added-on time, with Fulham equalizing on a most unlikely Goal of the Season worldie from Harrison Reed: just his fourth goal in over 200 appearances for the club.

HARRISON REED GOAL FROM ALL OF THE ANGLES WHAT A GOAL üòÆ‚Äçüí®üëèüèªpic.twitter.com/DZGfsF6Srw

‚Äî KinG ¬£ (@xKGx__) January 4, 2026

And they‚Äôve done all that despite losing a trio of key players to Nigeria at the Africa Cup of Nations (Alex Iwobi, Calvin Bassey, and Samuel Chukwueze), and missing a few others through injury (Josh King, Kenny Tete, and Rodrigo Muniz). In better news for them, Ryan Sessegnon looks set to return from a hamstring problem.

Manager Marco Silva is weary of the mental and physical tolls these games have taken on his players, though such concerns can fall by the wayside when it comes to special derbies (even friendly ones), especially when one side may feel wronged by a certain decision (i.e. Josh King‚Äôs goal getting ruled in the reverse fixture at the Bridge earlier this season).

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs special. It‚Äôs special, because we know what‚Äôs happened. [‚Ä¶] It really hurt ourselves, our fans, this football club, the way we were not able to win the game at Stamford Bridge. The way the team performed almost perfectly first half, in a really tough game against a top, top side, the way the team performed, and everything that happened in that game, really hurt this football club. I‚Äôm not talking about one or two persons, or just the players ‚Äì us, the football club, the way that things happened that Saturday morning.

‚ÄúIt is what it is ‚Äì now it‚Äôs another opportunity for us to enjoy, to embrace a big challenge with our fans to play a derby like a derby should be played. Simple as that. It‚Äôs a new game, a new story. I don‚Äôt want anyone to think about the past, we have to look for the future, and what‚Äôs going to be most important is the next one. It‚Äôs a special game.‚Äù

-Marco Silva; 

Chelsea team news: Robert S√°nchez and Wesley Fofana were both late scratches over the weekend, with injury and illness, respectively, but they are both back in training and in contention to start. Same goes for Marc Cucurella, who‚Äôs barely ever injured, but has missed the last couple games with a hamstring concern. We also welcome back Mois√©s Caicedo from his latest suspension.

Levi Colwill, D√°rio Essugo, and Rom√©o Lavia remain out. The club recently wished Mykhailo Mudryk a happy birthday on social media, so we should probably mention the suspended winger here as well. How‚Äôs the appeals process going, Misha?

McFarlane will be hoping to hand over the reigns to Rosenior with the team back on the right path.

‚Äú[This is a] really talented group, young, hungry, have shown they can play at the top top level against top top sides. Anyone associated with the club should be proud of their performance on Sunday and moving forward, this team has massive, massive potential so we should all be excited.‚Äù

-Calum McFarlane; 

Previously: Last season, we went to Craven Cottage on a low and came back on an absolute high. Tyrique George‚Äôs late equalizer and Pedro Neto‚Äôs even-later winner galvanized the team into a scorching hot run of form and results, culminating in not only a top-four finish but winning the FIFA Club World Cup later that summer.

title: Juventus dominate properly this time, see off Sassuolo
description: Juve‚Äôs most maligned player was key as Juve coasted to a win at an old bogey ground.
fullText:
All of three days ago, Juventus dominated their opponent, but didn‚Äôt use that dominance properly and ended up dropping points when they couldn‚Äôt convert that dominance to goals.

For a while, Tuesday night‚Äôs game against Sassuolo looked like it would be similar. Juve had at least managed to take score first after Pierre Kalulu‚Äôs cross was redirected by former Juve NextGen prospect Tarik Muharemovic into his own net 15 minutes in. But, despite once again sealing their opponents into their own half and refusing to let them out, Juventus once again couldn‚Äôt put the ball back into the net, seemingly leaving themselves open to paying a heavy price for a single mistake the way they had against Lecce.

The fact that they were at the Mapei Stadium ‚Äî a place that Juve had lost two straight years before the Neroverdi spent last year in Serie B ‚Äî jangled the nerves all the more.

But there were two big differences between Tuesday and Saturday. The first is that Juve didn‚Äôt make any boneheaded mistakes. The second was that Jonathan David ‚Äî their most maligned player after his catastrophic penalty miss over the weekend ‚Äî had his first true big game in a Juventus shirt, capping off an effective performance with an assist and a goal within two minutes of each other to propel the Bianconeri to a 3-0 victory to end the andata and match Roma and Como, who had both won earlier in the day, in order to stay ahead in the race for fourth place.

Luciano Spalletti was unable to carry the 4-2-3-1 formation he used against Lecce over to Tuesday‚Äôs match because of injuries at the back. Lloyd Kelly and Francisco Concei√ß√£o had taken minor knocks on Saturday and weren‚Äôt risked on the short turnaround, while Daniele Rugani, Federico Gatti, Jonas Rouhi, Dusan Vlahovic, and Arkadiusz Milik all joined them on the treatment table. With the defense stretched thin, Spalletti was forced to return to the 3-4-2-1. Michele Di Gregorio started in goal, fronted by Kalulu, Bremer, and Teun Koopmeiners. Weston McKennie and Andrea Cambiaso played at wing-back, sandwiching the usual midfield of Manuel Locatelli and Kh√©phren Thuram. Fabio Miretti joined Kenan Yildiz backing up David in attack.

Sassuolo was managed by former Juve defender and Italy legend Fabio Grosso, who was marking his 400th game as a first-team manager. He was missing a couple of his more recongnizable names, chief among them Domenico Berardi. Cristian Volpato, Filippo Romagna, Daniele Boloca, and Edoardo Pierangolo were also injured, and Woyo Coulibaly was playing for Mali at AFCON. Grosso deployed a 4-3-3, backstopped by goalkeeper Arijanet Muric. Sebastian Walukeiwicz, Jay Idzes, Muharemovic, and Josh Doig made up the back four. Isma√´l Kon√©, Edoardo Iannoni, and Nemanja Matic made up the midfield, while Kristian Thorstvedt and Armand Laurient√© flanked Andrea Pinamonti in the attacking trident.

It was actually Sassuolo who registered the first two shots of the game after Juve started fairly sloppily. Walukeiwicz poked a corner over less than two minutes in, and Thorstvedt jumped a bad pass only to fire wide two minutes after that. But soon the general flow of the game became quite clear: Juve going forward, Sassuolo struggling to break out.

In the ninth minute Yildiz stole the ball from Walukeiwicz at the corner of the box and tried to surprise Muric at the near post, but the keeper was able to parry before Cambiaso put the rebound into the side netting from a tight angle. David found Thuram for the first of his six (six!) key passes on the night a few minutes later, but the Frenchman‚Äôs shot went righ at Muric.

But the Kosovar keeper could do nothing just after the quarter-hour mark, when Kalulu came forward to aid the attack and sent in a cross. He was looking for the run of Miretti in the middle, but his ball was met by the head of Muharemovic, who was trying to clear but instead glanced it into his own net, far from anywhere where Muric could hope to intervene. The promising young center-back‚Äôs mistake gave Juve what they‚Äôd never managed at the Allianz over the weekend: a lead.

The next task was to consolidate that lead ‚Äî which the team had problems doing. David tried to twist a ball in at a tight angle from the right but couldn‚Äôt beat Muric, while Yildiz had two shots denied sandwiched around the half-hour mark. The young Turk had another opportunity five minutes before the break, this time hitting a powerful shot across goal that Muric again had to parry, lucky to hit it right at Idzes, who reacted well to clear.

Juve came out of the gate looking to kill the game off, but were still having issues doing just that. Locatelli must have thought he‚Äôd spotted Muric off his line a few minutes after kickoff, because he hit a long-distance lob that flew well over the goal, beforee Thuram was sent down the left channel but elected to go himself instead of feeding one of three runners to his right, forcing a relatively easy save out of Muric. Miretti joined the effort and stabbed a square pass from David over from inside the box, and it looked as though the frustration might be starting to mount.

But only two minutes later, David connected with Miretti again, to much better results. McKennie chested a long ball down and passed it to David, who quickly side-footed the ball into the path of Miretti. He tore past Muharemovic and into the right channel, then ripped the ball past Muric and into the far side of the net. It was his first goal in 10 months and his first goal for Juventus in nearly two years.

Within 109 seconds, David had stomped out any chance the hosts might‚Äôve had for a comeback. Pressure from the Canadian forced Idzes into a horrific back pass that the striker pounced on. He dribbled the ball around Muric and kept his cool as he slotted home past Walukeiwicz‚Äôs feeble attempt to swipe it off the line. The unity of the team then showed out. After so much criticism‚Äîas well as reports that David was an outsider in the locker room‚Äîthe entire team, on the field and on the bench, mobbed him. Even Spalletti ran downfield to celebrate with the man he‚Äôd shown a vote of confidence by starting him again.

He almost added another seconds later when another bad turnover in the Sassuolo box fell to him, but this time he fired high. But at that point it mattered little‚Äîthe game was well and truly over. Both sides knew they were simply playing out the stretch, and the rhythm of the game reflected it. Sassuolo did finally put a shot on target in the 84th minute when Nicholas Pierini tested Di Gregorio from a direct free kick, then Luca Lipani added another on the ensuing corner that Juve‚Äôs keeper again met with a parry.

There was little to do for the defense besides that, and as the final whistle blared out across the Mapei Stadium, the Bianconeri walked toward the traveling fans to celebrate their first win at the ground since 2022, and to closing out the andata in style.

title: What Becky Burke and Arizona players said after win over BYU
description: Arizona women‚Äôs basketball won its first Big 12 game of the Becky Burke era Tuesday night by taking down BYU at McKale Center. For a team that had dropped its first three conferences games, the victory was much-needed. What changed Tuesday? Burke credited the performance to the team‚Äôs all-around effort level. ‚ÄúBYU plays extremely hard.
fullText:
Arizona women‚Äôs basketball won its first Big 12 game of the Becky Burke era Tuesday night by taking down BYU at McKale Center. For a team that had dropped its first three conferences games, the victory was much-needed.

What changed Tuesday? Burke credited the performance to the team‚Äôs all-around effort level.

‚ÄúBYU plays extremely hard. We played harder,‚Äù Burke said. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre capable of it. We‚Äôve shown it now. Now that‚Äôs the standard.‚Äù

Now that Arizona has its first Big 12 win in the bag, Burke believes her team is capable of playing with the same type of energy on a nightly basis.

‚ÄúBecause I think this is a group that when they when they do something well, and get rewarded for it and see the fruits of their labor, I think they then want to do more of it,‚Äù Burke said.‚Äú

Our recap of the game can be found here. Below is what Burke, Nora Francois, Sumayah Sugapong and Tanyuel Welch had to say after the game.

Burke on her overall thoughts on the win: ‚ÄúI am overjoyed. I‚Äôm so excited for our group. You know, we needed this. We worked our butts off for this. That‚Äôs a really, really, really good team. I‚Äôve played, I‚Äôve won games, I‚Äôve done it. Like I am so happy for them. For a lot of these, literally, all three of these guys to win their first Power 4 games, especially here in Arizona, it‚Äôs really special. And we were just talking through the first three games of big 12 play. We just got to keep battling, stay the course, and when we get our first one, what that is going to do for this team, to just rejuvenate them and build that confidence, that they can go win games if we play the way that we play today. So shout out to our staff and coach Julie game plan was absolutely phenomenal. Shout out to them for executing it to perfection and pairing that with being the hardest game. You know, our effort that was, that was they‚Äôve played the hardest they‚Äôve played all season tonight. So I could not be more happy for these guys.‚Äù

On Arizona‚Äôs defensive intensity: ‚ÄúWell we forced them into 27 turnovers. I didn‚Äôt think it was going to be that high, but, like, I knew we could turn them over. Oheir offense is very, very, very ball screen oriented. There‚Äôs one, two, maybe three on every possession. A lot of people have just been letting them use ball screens this year, and they‚Äôre so good at picking you apart. They‚Äôll take anything you give them off ball screens. So we just said we‚Äôre gonna shake some stuff up. We‚Äôre not gonna let them use ball screens and do what they want. We‚Äôre going to dictate defensively. Our ball pressure, and then Nora hedged ball screens for 40 minutes like I‚Äôve never seen before, you know. So it was just a tremendous effort by them, but to force a minute 27 turnovers, it‚Äôs really hard to win when you turn the ball over that many times. So just just credit to our group for doing that and causing those.‚Äù

On asking Francois to hedging ball screens, and what Francois brought offensively: ‚ÄúWe had a horrible trip back from Texas Tech, and we‚Äôre getting off the plane, and we prepped on the airplane for the next one, and Nora is getting off. And I‚Äôm like, Nora, can you hedge a ball screen? She‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòVery well, actually.‚Äô I‚Äôm like, okay, so she proved herself right today. What she did on the defensive end, I think, like, had just helped her flow offensively. I mean, she was very effective on the defensive end. It‚Äôs easy when you guard and you do what you‚Äôre supposed to do on that end, to have some juice and to have, like, to go sprint to screens. It was really nice to see. And our guards fed her the ball, like, extremely well. She created for herself some. Our guards created for her some. And then she was finishing today, which is the most encouraging thing, you know, because she‚Äôs gonna make a couple, she‚Äôs gonna miss a couple. That‚Äôs kind of what we‚Äôve been living with all year. But she was making them today, and the focus was there. She would say the same thing, and she probably will, but like, credit to the guards too. Nora was screening, rolling and posting, and we were feeding her. like we just kept going to what was working. And that‚Äôs just like, such, such high IQ by our players, without me having to like, walk them through every little thing.‚Äù

On getting Sugapong back in the lineup: ‚ÄúYeah, a lot of it‚Äôs been like game plan. size of opponents. I told Sumayah the other day, it‚Äôs really hard to have you and Lani on the floor at the same time, given this game plan and how aggressive we were going to be and how they‚Äôre very guard oriented. We knew Sumayah could play a ton of this game, and she did, you know. So it‚Äôs really not a Sumayah thing, it‚Äôs a game plan, personnel on the other teams thing, you know. So it was, it was nice to see her go out there and just pick up where she left off. And the tight rotation today, I told everybody in practice like I‚Äôm going with who‚Äôs going to do what I‚Äôm asking him to do at a really high level. So if it‚Äôs five or six, the rest of the way, we‚Äôll call plenty of timeouts, we‚Äôll get plenty of treatment, and we‚Äôll see what these guys got. But the five or six that played the heavy minutes tonight were the ones that were getting it done. So if it‚Äôs not broke, I‚Äôm not going to fix it.‚Äù

On the number of hustle plays and playing with a higher effort level: ‚ÄúYeah, the chart is in my brain. When I see our players on the floor, left and right, it fires me up. Like that is who we have to be. Our slogan is sleeves up. They rolled their sleeves up today. Got dirty like there was no question that we played harder. And BYU plays extremely hard. We played harder. We‚Äôre capable of it. We‚Äôve shown it now. Now that‚Äôs the standard. Like, we have to be that team. We‚Äôve proven, like we did tonight, that if we‚Äôre that team and we can play that hard every night, we‚Äôll give ourselves a chance every single time. These kind of 50/50 games we‚Äôll win. These will sneak a couple that we‚Äôre not supposed to win, you know, but we have to play this hard and harder the rest of the way. You know, you saw a little two, two minute stretch. We didn‚Äôt play super hard. What happened? Boom, 14 to 4 run. We have to play hard the rest of the season. They can rest in April, like, we have to play hard. So, but I like, to your point, there was a zero question. And the fans love it. I mean, I loved, like, I loved doing that stuff, because I love the fans cheering for me like that on the floor. You want them to, like, cheer for you, right? Like, you want to feel good. You want like, yeah, we got it. We got to do that stuff, especially in the atmosphere that we have here. It just fires everybody up.‚Äù

On the support of the fanbase and the significance of beating BYU: ‚ÄúThis is how special this place is. I mean, we just started conference play 0-3 and this might have been one of our biggest crowds. That is why I took this job there. We‚Äôre obviously going to battle and fight this year and make everybody proud and do a great job and have a lot of momentum. But like, we want to recruit the best players in the country here. We want to win a national championship here. Why would somebody not want to come to a place that, when we‚Äôre 0-3 in the Big 12, you still get to play in front of 8,000 people? It is an incredibly unique place when it comes to that. I was excited. I knew we were going to get one. It was a matter of when it was. Because I think this is a group that when they when they do something well, and get rewarded for it and see the fruits of their labor, I think they then want to do more of it. And I think they then want to continue what they did to have that success. Yeah, it was really hard for us to get it right? Three games. But like now that they‚Äôve got it, I think they‚Äôre going to be locked in for the UCF game plan the same way that they were for this one. I think they‚Äôre going to trust us a little bit more than if we do exactly what we‚Äôre asking them to do, that, hey, it actually worked. That‚Äôs what type of group this is. So if they needed one to go get two or three in these next few, then I‚Äôm glad we kind of got the monkey off our back a little bit. But I told them, if you get even a little bit complacent and you think because you beat BYU that we‚Äôve arrived, you‚Äôre gonna drop one on Saturday. This is an every night league, and we can‚Äôt take our foot off the gas at all.‚Äù

On how the team can offset rebounding struggles: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre boxing out. It‚Äôs the pursuit to go get it after we box out. There wasn‚Äôt a whole lot of shot, like we turned them over 27 times. So that‚Äôs 27 shots. They didn‚Äôt take for us to rebound it. So I think some of those stats are a little bit skewed sometimes. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, we‚Äôre not a great rebounding team ever, but yeah, I‚Äôd rather live steals than rebounds in this game, particularly, T goes and snatches a bunch. But we have to be better at hitting and going and pursuing the ball.‚Äù

On preparing for UCF: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt talk or think about the next team until we take care of business with the first team. You look at scores in the league, it‚Äôs just what we do, right? But no, I don‚Äôt have to know anything about them to know that we need to bring our best on Saturday. We need to play high level basketball. We need to build off this momentum. We need to be extremely locked in.‚Äù

On the possibility of starting Big 12 play 2-3: ‚ÄúIt would be huge. These are so hard earned and hard to get. They know how hard that win was out there? Like, I‚Äôm glad they have an off day tomorrow, because they need it, you know? So it‚Äôs big, but we could also be 1-4, so they got to be locked.‚Äù

Francois on executing on defense, particularly hedges: ‚ÄúSo actually, on the plane leaving our last game, coach asked me, she‚Äôs like, ‚ÄòNora, do you know how to hedge?‚Äô I was like, ‚ÄòThis is my time to shine. This is my time.‚Äô Definitely very familiar with hard hedging, soft hedging, anything. Drop coverage is fine, but just being prepared for that, going into practice, knowing that I‚Äôm gonna have my moments. That was really the biggest adjustment.‚Äù

On knocking the ball away in late defensive stand: ‚ÄúI read the inbounder‚Äôs eyes, and she was trying so hard not to look at my person. So I was like, All right, it‚Äôs coming to her. So I just got her arm up, tipped it, thankfully. Sumayah turned around, secured it and yeah.‚Äù

On her chemistry with Lani Cornfield: ‚ÄúI had to make an adjustment. I‚Äôm used to picking and rolling and putting my hand up to get the ball up here, but with Lani, it‚Äôs a lot of bounce passes, so making sure you know your hands are ready. Yeah, because she‚Äôll find you. She‚Äôll find you.‚Äù

Sugapong on going 9-9 from the free throw line: ‚ÄúMy teammates trusts me with the ball down this stretch, which does a lot for my confidence. And then, you know, all the hours in the gym, just getting a free throws and free throws, that‚Äôs what gave me the confidence to step up those shots and knock them down.‚Äú

On staying ready when she wasn‚Äôt playing as much: ‚ÄúYeah, just mentally staying locked in. I mean, I trust the coaches their game plan going into every game. So just for sure just staying locked in, being ready when my number‚Äôs called.‚Äù

Welch on the importance of the home crowd: ‚ÄúOne thing I can say, after being on the road for two games, we definitely missed being at home and having those fans. It don‚Äôt matter what‚Äôs going on in the game. We could be down, we could be up, we could be having, like, a bad stretch, the other team could have a stretch, but they really helped change the momentum for us. You know, we get a little stop and they‚Äôll make it seem like we just won the championship. So a little stuff like that really, really helps our team.‚Äù

On being healthy and having six straight games in double figures: ‚ÄúThe beginning the season, I had a concussion. You know, I had to work my way back in, work back from my spot. So I just took pride and wanted to be on the floor. I do whatever it takes to help my team. As you can see, I rebounded really well tonight, and I feel like that‚Äôs what we needed the most. BYU is really good at crashing the boards as far as offenses, so I made sure I secured it. And as far as my performance go, I just feel like I play a big role for this team, whether I‚Äôm scoring or not. On both ends of the floor, offensively and defensively, I set the tone. So with that being said, I have to be there. I have to be present for my team. Also like to use my voice and keep us together and huddle and all that. So yeah, just using that energy and letting my hard work show.‚Äù

On staying locked in: ‚ÄúI mean, now that we got our first one, I feel like it would give us a lot more momentum going into these next ones. I feel like we all can agree that tonight was fun. We enjoyed the game. So why wouldn‚Äôt we want to just keep growing from here, you know, making it exciting and growing together and just learning throughout the season. So I feel like this win tonight would really help.‚Äù

On what it takes to maintain defensive energy: ‚ÄúWell, you got to do it or you‚Äôre coming out the game. So I feel like that‚Äôs the first part of it. And I mean, those are the type of plays that, if we‚Äôre not going offensively, those turn into transition points. There‚Äôs just type of plays we need to win games, and everybody wants to win so everybody‚Äôs out there playing 100%.‚Äù

title: Liverpool give Juventus conditions for Federico Chiesa deal
description: It‚Äôs been another frustrating season for Federico Chiesa. Although the Italian winger has made himself a crowd favourite throughout his short time at Anfield he has been unable to win over Arne Slot...
fullText:
It‚Äôs been another frustrating season for Federico Chiesa.

Although the Italian winger has made himself a crowd favourite throughout his short time at Anfield he has been unable to win over Arne Slot decisively.

Used sparingly during the 2024/25 Premier League title-winning campaign, Chiesa has admittedly played more this term.

He fought back during the summer to become a first-team option for Slot - but he has only managed one Premier League start in the season to this point.

As a result of his lack of game time, it‚Äôs been suggested that the 28-year-old could be moving back to Serie A.

Roma have been mentioned as possible suitors but now it seems that Liverpool could be willing to do business with Juventus over a potential deal.

Shop the goalkeeper range today

Shop the third kit range today!

Sporting director Richard Hughes signed Chiesa from Juventus for ¬£12m back in September 2024 with the Italy international inking a deal until 2028.

And according to a report on Sky Sports the Anfield club would be willing to offload Chiesa this January - but there is one condition attached.

The English side will NOT entertain a loan move for Chiesa but would like to sell him on a permanent basis instead.

‚ÄúJuventus has inquired with the player's representatives to see if there are any opportunities to bring him back to Italy on loan. Liverpool has been open to the move, but only on a permanent basis,‚Äù the report reads.

The source also mentions that Napoli have been in touch about a loan move.

And according to Gazzetta dello Sport Chiesa has now responded to Juventus‚Äô transfer interest - and WOULD be willing to move back to Turin this winter.

‚ÄúAfter hearing the Italian winger's openness to a possible return to the Bianconeri, Juventus officials have expressed their interest in welcoming the player back to Continassa, exploring whether the Reds would be willing to open negotiations in the second half of January,‚Äù the report reads.

A deal could be concluded in the second half of the month owing to Liverpool‚Äôs shortage up top right now.

Hugo Ekitike has been carrying an injury, Alexander Isak is out following a broken leg and Mohamed Salah is away at AFCON. But once those issues begin to resolve we could see an exit for Chiesa materialise very rapidly.

title: 'Yamagata is ramen': Japan's city of noodle fiends revels in 'capital' status
description: Noodle dish is nation‚Äôs favourite comfort food and source of civic pride ‚Äì but it has health risks
fullText:
Noodle dish is nation‚Äôs favourite comfort food and source of civic pride ‚Äì but it has health risks

The road to ramen paradise ends in the unlikeliest of places. At Men Endo, located in a suburban street, next to a school and a low-rise apartment block, bowls of noodles disappear in a flurry of slurps, gulps and hurried but heartfelt exchanges of appreciation between customer and chef.

On a cold afternoon in Yamagata, a city in Japan‚Äôs northeast, the wait for a seat at Men Endo‚Äôs counter is mercifully short. Inside the door, a ticket dispenser lists myriad options, from regular shoyu (soy sauce) ramen ‚Äì in small, medium or large portions ‚Äì to maji soba, a soupless symphony of toppings, sauce and noodles that diners are invited to mix together with their chopsticks, along with a spoonful of spicy miso.

That Men Endo ‚Äì men is from menrui, the Japanese word for noodles, and Endo is a family name ‚Äì has managed to secure a loyal clientele ‚Äì which today includes construction workers, couples and a solo diner from the Guardian ‚Äì is no mean feat.

In Yamagata, 340km north of Tokyo, noodle fiends have around 230 establishments to choose from, with several opening their doors early for those craving comfort food.

‚ÄúPeople here don‚Äôt ask each other where they want to go for dinner, but which ramen restaurant to go to,‚Äù says Osamu Higuchi, assistant manager in Yamagata‚Äôs brand strategy section.

It is that level of dedication to eating at restaurants ‚Äì as opposed to making ramen at home or grabbing a lunchtime cup of the instant variety ‚Äì that has earned Yamagata, a modestly sized city of 240,000, the title of Japan‚Äôs ramen capital.

The accolade is a source of pride, its current reign the result of an aggressive campaign to outperform its closest rival, Niigata, which shocked the ramen world by taking the title in 2021.

Last year, Yamagata‚Äôs households each spent an average of ¬•22,389 [¬£106] on ramen ‚Äì well ahead of second-placed Niigata on ¬•16,292, according to the internal affairs ministry, which will soon announce the winner for 2025. Only the annual ranking for gyoza consumption generates similar levels of anticipation. That title currently belongs to Hamamatsu in central Japan.

‚ÄúWhen Niigata won it was a huge shock,‚Äù says Higuchi. ‚ÄúEating ramen is a big part of daily life here ‚Ä¶ to be honest it hurt our feelings.‚Äù

But the city‚Äôs appetite for ramen has its drawbacks. Frequent consumption can increase health risks, mainly due to the soup‚Äôs high salt content, according to a study of almost 7,000 people aged 40 and over led by Yamagata University. People who have the dish three or more times a week have a mortality risk 1.52 times higher than those who eat it once or twice a week, according to the four-year study published in October in the Journal of Nutrition, Health and Aging.

The experts added, however, that the statistics did not mean regular consumption was a ‚Äúdefinite danger‚Äù, given that those most at risk possibly indulged in other habits ‚Äúcommon among frequent ramen‚Äù eaters, such as excessive overall salt intake, drinking and smoking.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been trying not to drink all of the soup, but it‚Äôs very moreish, and the chefs go to a lot of effort to make it so it feels rude to leave any,‚Äù says Higuchi who, after consulting a smartphone app, announces he has polished off 225 bowls of ramen so far this year. ‚ÄúThat said, households here spend an average of about ¬•2,000 a month on ramen ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs not that much when you think about it.‚Äù

Health risks aside, no Japanese dish commands as much loyalty, or generates as much discussion, as ramen. Popularised in Japan after the second world war ‚Äì thanks to returning soldiers who fondly recalled how it had sustained them in Japanese-occupied China ‚Äì it became a symbol of recovery and resilience.

Ramen critic Rikiya Yamaji believes Yamagata has perfected the art of adapting what was originally a Chinese dish to suit the Japanese palate. ‚ÄúRamen has been around in Japan since the Meiji era [1868-1912], but became particularly popular when it was served at food stalls after the war,‚Äù said Yamaji, who gets through 30 bowls a month and has been known to visit several ramen shops a day.

‚ÄúA distinctive feature of Japanese food culture is its ability to ‚Äòlocalise‚Äô dishes introduced from overseas ‚Ä¶ curry rice is a good example. In the same way, ramen has evolved into new food culture with a uniquely Japanese approach, like Tex-Mex cuisine in the US. It used to be considered cheap and filling, and it‚Äôs still convenient and inexpensive, but these days there is more emphasis on quality and fusion ingredients.‚Äù

The noodle dish with humble origins is now the yardstick by which Japan‚Äôs regions measure their culinary cach√©, triggering fierce rivalries and competing claims to have achieved the perfect marriage of soup, noodles and toppings. Varieties range from miso ramen in the far north, to those sitting in a pale but pungent pork-based broth in the deep south.

The roots of Yamagata‚Äôs obsession lie in the aftermath of the 1923 Great Kant≈ç Earthquake, which killed more than 100,000 people in the Tokyo area. Ramen chefs who fled the destroyed capital to work at soba restaurants in Yamagata shared their ramen-making skills and found a population with an appetite for steaming hot noodles to get them through the city‚Äôs bitterly cold winters. Households would order ramen, rather than trays of sushi, to serve to guests ‚Äì a custom that gave children an early introduction to a dish they continued to eat into adulthood.

After it ceded its title to Niigata a few years ago, ramen shop owners and officials in Yamagata teamed up to create an organisation dedicated to re-establishing the city as Japan‚Äôs ‚Äúramen kingdom‚Äù.

Higuchi is confident Yamagata will retain the title when the government announces the 2025 results in early February. ‚ÄúIf our ramen businesses do well, then so does the local economy ‚Äì farmers and soy sauce manufacturers, even the companies that produce hot towels for restaurants,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs going too far to say that Yamagata is ramen.‚Äù
